												Honestly, the best game of its kind. It has some of the wittiest and most amusing story lines ,dark and mature mixed with tragedy that will take you by surprise.Beautiful visual design, great mix of colors and nicely put together levels that will remind you of Tim Burton's films. Voice acting & dialogues are excellent as you would come to expect with Tim Schafer produced games.Fun combat & platforming mechanics, they serve their purpose but are nothing ground breaking and some of the segments can overstay their welcome slightly.One part i found was annoying was that you have to grind for money to purchase an item to progress further, which interrupts the pacing somewhat.All in all a great title which is sadly overlooked by people. Highly recommend to any one who likes FUN.

												Psychonauts is this type of game, that was made with love and passion firstly and business strategy lastly in mind.On the positive side: Art vision and design level are top notch. Every world in game feels, looks and plays very differently; Original premise for story and whole plotline is very engaging; Clever and funny writing; New powers (12 in total, which is more than enough) unlocked through the game make gameplay fresh till the end;On the negative side: Some collectibles are very hard to see, so collecting them could be frustrating experience; Sometimes camera decides you are having too much fun and it is time to make your life worse; Cutscenes pre-rendered in a low resolution (800x600 i think). Because of that they look very bad;tl;dr: you should play it if you like platformers/adventure, good original story, creative art and want something unique to experience.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: Psychonauts Original Release: 2005 Genre Tags: Adventure; RPG; Platformer; Lighthearted; Psychedelic My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-25 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamersREVIEWPsychonauts is a quirky and imaginative action-adventure game that is an absolute riot.  It is an aging specimen, but it will forever hold a status as a highly enjoyable “cult classic.”  If it has piqued your interest, then I suggest you take a complimentary cup of Kool-Aid and join the cult… you won’t regret it.Psychonauts excels at many things.  The story, the characters, and the writing are all top-notch and well-executed.  The scenes and developments throughout the campaign are quite amusing and should keep you thoroughly entertained.  The many different characters are all interesting in their own way.  They are all splendidly eccentric and unique, if not also reminiscent of typical Saturday-morning-cartoon archetypes.  And, importantly, the voice acting is mostly decent and sufficiently holds everything else together… although it does falter slightly, on occasion.   Providing setting for the narrative is a very inspired and diverse gameworld that is quite atmospheric.  The graphics used are undeniably dated and are only increasingly falling farther behind the curve; however the developers did an outstanding job of matching the environments and atmosphere to the overall soul of the game.  There is a mixture of lighthearted, noir, cartoonish, and psychedelic ambiances which really diversifies the experience as you play through the campaign.   You may not be awed by the scenery like in modern games, but you can still easily appreciate the effort that was put into the creation of the gameworld.Of course, the intriguing narrative and captivating atmosphere would be for naught if the gameplay wasn’t enjoyable.  Luckily, Psychonauts is quite fun to play.  There is a pleasant mixture of combat situations and puzzle-solving that you would expect from a game like this.  Situations can be approached by experimentation with various abilities and skills, which you unlock as you progress through the campaign.  Also, the various levels will introduce different dynamics to keep you on your toes.  There are also a ton of collectibles and many achievements to keep you busy, if you are into that kind of thing.Psychonauts can easily appeal to a wide and diverse audience.  The tone is fairly childish, but has many adult themes.  It is also a pretty easy/casual experience, so there shouldn’t be any skill issues.  It takes approximately 14 to 22 hours to complete, depending on if you strive for achievements or not.  If you like 3D action-adventure platformers, I would say this is a pretty safe bet for you.  It is also a good bet for anyone who may be interested in “seeing what the fuss is about,” as you will probably find it enjoyable once given a try.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												     Personally this is my favorite Double Fine game. Although it is about nine years old it still holds up as a good game with an interesting art style. Unlike most games built as an atempt at photorealism, the extremely cartoonish graphics and garish colour palette still looks good almost a decade after release. As all games from Tim Schafer the writing is magnificent, the voice acting is well done and the characters always have something important or hilarious to say. The setting of a Summer camp for Psychics not only influences the plot and gameplay but the dialogues actually sound like something children at summer camp would be saying, except that they are about the outlandish topics involved with a world surrounded by psychic weirdness. The gameplay is devided up into two sections, the overworld with some, but not much combat, sidequests, the one shop in the game, and most of the colorful non-essential dialogue, and the insides of the various character's minds. These minds serve as the various levels of the game, each with the same basic controlls but slightly different gameplay. The Meat Circus level is all about fast paced platforming, whilst Lungfishopolis is completely based on the combat system, and the Milkman level(BEST LEVEL EVER) is an old school inventory adventure puzzle mixed with a fever dream X-Files Plot. Throughout the game you gain psy powers that are used in combat and level navigation, some work as a long range attack with the need to collect ammo, and there is a bouncy ball/parachute power that makes platforming much more difficult and interesting.     Now that i have sufficiently gushed about all the things i freaking love about this game it is time to get realistic and talk about the flaws. Most of these flaws have to do with the fact that this was Double Fine's first attempt at an action game. the combat can be a bit annoying with enemy spamming getting overdone at times, that being said most of the basic enemies are too easy to dispatch and clearing the room becomes simply a chore without much actual difficulty. The controlls are somewhat soft and the platforming would be vastly improved by tighter controlls to allow for fine tuned navigation. and if you watch a let's play you can see that the dificulty scale starts off low but when it does ramp up it does so without telling you and later levels,(Milkman,Meat Circus) can become frustrating and take forever to get past, not allways from dificulty of combat or platforming but in the milkman level if you do not know what you are doing it can be almost impossible to figure some of the puzzles out organically.     All that being said these flaws are really not as bad as it sounds. the increased difficulty lends less to frustraton and more to angry inspiration to just beat this next level and prove that you are better than the game. and for the milkman, a quick glance at a gameFAQ can help if you get too badlt stuck, enough people have been frustrated by the level to have wonderfull walkthroughs made to relieve the tension. in the end the story and experience is so good it makes up for any akwardness in gameplay. 8/10, This game is a love it or hate it, and i love it, fantastic but not even close to perfect.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Psychonauts has to be one the greatest Adventure/Platformers of our time, it succeeds in achieving the best aspects of the genre. The controls are tight allowing for great platforming and visually still looks better than most games today. The Steam version of Psychonauts is brilliant, I have not experienced a single bug and it supports HD. The exploration this game offers is top-notch, you get to explore a large camp littered with clever secrets and challenges along with some of the most insane levels. The combat is entertaining, especially since you get decent upgrades and new powers as you go along, allowing you to form more strategies so it never feels like a boring slogfest.The art direction of Psychonauts is unlike any other game and is vibrant and unique, you have to wonder what the devs were on when making some of the characters and the sound/soundtrack do their job pretty well. The way this game progresses in terms of difficulty and design is persistent and can get fairly challenging later on in the game. The dialogue is extremely well done adding a lot of life to some of the strangest looking characters in video gaming. The game features a dark/twisted humour which adds to the hilarity of the situations you encounter.This game gets much better the further you get, the levels get much more abstract and crazier, theres a few here which are total masterpieces and the plot is surprisingly deep for a game of this nature and extremely entertaining. The amount of imagination put into this game is amazing, the art direction is it's own, the characters are brilliant, the level design is solid, the combat and platforming are tight, the atmosphere is effective, the humour is hilarious as hell and never feels like they tried hard to make it that way, so it doesn't feel forced like many other games that try achieve a comical effect and is loaded with charm, there really is nothing negative about this game. To get this on Steam is a no brainer as it's an incredibly solid experience that should be experienced by anyone who appreciates Adventure and platforming games and timeless classics. Squirrels are liars.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
 Psychonauts is one of the best games I’ve ever played. In this long post I will describe in detail why that is true. Psychonauts is a 3D platformer game with very peculiar art style, great characters and awesome story line. 1. Story & Characters  (Spoiler Free don’t worry)The main place where almost every action of the game takes place is a summer camp for children with psychic abilities (Something like X-Men). The main character is named Razputin, Raz for short, a young child which goes alone to that summer camp without his father’s permission.There are around 20 kids in the camp and you can interact with every one of them. There are also a couple of adults which are training the young psychics. The main story is very interesting and will hook you in. I don’t want to say anything related to it because I don’t want to spoil something unintentionally All children[i.imgur.com]2. Gameplay & Graphics.The gameplay is very solid; you have a lot of things to do. The game feels very open world to me. It has 6 separated locations plus a couple more which are not placed on the map. The game features very common gameplay mechanics: Double jump (later on you will acquire something with which you will jump even higher), normal punch attack and 3 slots for special attacks. I highly hope you will ignore the graphics, because they are not so good and hope you will give the game a chance.I highly doubt they will remaster it so no need to wait.3.  Level design.This by far is the best aspect of the game. They are so well made, with high attention to details -  almost perfect. I will always remember 2 levels in my mind: Waterloo World and Milkman Conspiracy.  Both are in the later part of the game. The Waterloo World has such awesome ideas and I will try to explain it without any spoilers. In that level your body can exist in 3 states - Large (normal), medium and small. In order to beat the level, you need to switch between the states and interact with stuff whereby you can’t in other states. Milkman Conspiracy is so abstract it makes you question your sanity (Please don’t think it’s too deep). There are very nice gameplay mechanics in this level and you need to get used to it quite fast so you can beat it (A lot of backtracking for achievement hunters). Almost every level introduces its own gameplay mechanic. And that’s why the game is so good. You never feel bored with it.4. Comedy.Comedy plays a big part in the game. Almost every character is funny on its own. You’ll never feel that a joke is forced. Every joke is balanced and put right on spot. There are 2 abilities which I used more often than necessary, just because they made situations way funnier. The first ability is called Bacon - when you use it, a character appears in your mind and tells you his advice on the current situation, points out weak spots for the boss fights and sometimes makes funny jokes. The other is an ability acquired later on the game, which allows you to see yourself through the eyes of others and - oh, boy - I laughed my♥♥♥♥♥off with that. The developers put a lot of effort into this ability to show different pictures of you for everything that you can view yourself through. I’m sure I did not get all the jokes and I’m sure there are many more. Seen by a thing which loves cake[i.imgur.com]5. Abilities & Ranking system.There are in total 101 PSI cadet ranks. Once you have gathered a PSI Core combined with 9 PSI cards to it, you are granted a cadet rank. You need to buy a lot of PSI Cores from the in-game shop. There is no such thing as a skill tree in this game. The game gives you abilities when you reach certain cadet rank.6. AchievementsThis is for all who are going to attempt to get all achievements:Most achievements are fairly easy and you will find no problem getting them. Many are story related so you can’t miss them. A couple are quite tricky because if you progress too far in a current level you can’t obtain them anymore.  I used a spoiler-free guide to see when I should take a minute and visit a place.There are 3 very hard achievements:  "I LOVE PUNCHING!" I think this achievement takes place in the very first big level and - oh, boy, believe me - it’s very hard. The problem is that it requires skill but the controls are poorly done for PC users. It’s a living nightmare to do it with keyboard and mouse. I’ve read that it’s easier to achieve with controller. I’ve put in a lot of effort to obtain it. (You will need this achievement for “Math is Hard” achievement)Another very hard achievement is called:"Math is Hard". If you are a collectible hunter by nature you will find no problem in getting this achievement. Briefly explained: you need to collect everything before the POINT OF NO RETURN. And yes there is a certain point where you can’t go back. Personally I’m not a big fan of such implementations, because everyone can ♥♥♥♥ up. At least they put a handy “Save” with the same name (POINT OF NO RETURN) and if you think you’ve missed something you can reload that save and complete those things you’ve missed.The last “hard” achievement is actually not hard at all. It requires you to buy an item from the in-game store (it’s not micro-transaction) on Christmas. I know you can change your PC date and get the achievement very easily, but since Christmas is very close I decided to wait.7. CollectiblesThere are 7 types of collectibles: Figments, Vaults, Emotional Baggage, PSI cards(PSI cards+core), Scavenger hunt items, Brains and Cobwebs. In any part of the map, when you open the menu it shows how many collectibles you can find. There are a lot of figments - like 100 per level and sometimes they blend so much with the level itself it is hard to find them. Vaults are really interesting,  they share screenshots of a certain character’s past and it’s made like an old movie - I love those. There are very messed up vaults which really can affect your mood after seeing them. Emotional Baggages are collected in a strange way. Imagine it to be doors -  you need to find the key and the door itself; sometimes you will find the door before the key.  Usually on every part of the map there are a certain number of PSI cards and like 1 PSI Core (with cards). There are 16 scavenger hunt items in total and some are quite hard to find. Once you gather 8, you are granted 4 levels at once. When you find the rest you get another 4 levels.  Cobwebs are tricky because you need a tool from the in-game shop in order to collect them. Usually there are 5-6 per level. Once gathered you can redeem them for PSI cards.Overall they are fun to collect. You need all of collectibles for “Math is Hard” achievement.All collectables[i.imgur.com]8. How I got to know of this game.FunHause YouTube channel is a channel which I watch very often. One of the members of this channel kept talking about this game non-stop and eventually I checked it out. His name is James  Williems9. Psychonauts 2The game raised 3.5 million dollars through crowdfunding from investors and other people. And I’m super-duper hyped for the second game. They even gave James Williams a voice acting role because he did an insane job popularising the game. Video from the developers10. Final verdict and thoughts.On a scale from 0 to 10, I will give  Psychonauts 9/10 without a doubt. It’s one hell of a good game and with this kind of a review I hope it made you check it out yourself. Huge respect to Double Fine for creating such a good game.Awesome credit picture[i.imgur.com]

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												My previous review of this game did not do it justice since I felt it deserved better than that - I'd like to elaborate a bit further on why I love this game ever so much as one of the best innovative games/platformers of all time. Growing up with 2D and 3D platformers like Mario, Crash & Spyro I could easily adapt to the platforming of the game. The platforming itself is solid enough but the actual combat in the game, during times like Boss Battles, can be dodgy as heck if you don't have a controller in handy -- Usually because of several different buttons needed to lock-on enemies and attack or alternatively dodge incoming attacks. You have the option of changing the keys to fit a play-style suitable for yourself, but I still find it frustrating at best namely due to the several important commands required. Here's my advice: Play the game with a controller as it'll make gameplay a bit smoother. So, what makes the game exceptional? Well, first of all it's the premise. The setting is a summer school camp for psychics. The game is brought to us by none other than the master of adventure games, Tim Schäfer (Monkey Island, Grim Fandango, Day of the Tentacle), whose characteristic sense of humor certainly blooms in Psychonauts. One of the long running concepts of Schäfer's style usually juxtaposes a rather mundane situation in a fantastical setting; Such as what you'd expect if Tim Burton & David Lynch teamed up for an all-wacky-superstar tag team line up movie. Which is just as well because creator Tim Schäfer has now acquired his very own Johnny Depp, in form of Jack Black, although he's absent from this game. But I digress - We play as Raz, who's chosen to flee from the circus as opposed to joining it, because being a Psychonaut is a lot more fulfilling than the circus obviously. As he gets accepted into the fold of Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp he soon finds himself in the middle of a strange conspiracy, where the brains of the camp's inhabitants mysteriously vanish which leads to the game's funniest moments. The caricatures that show up in the game are so incredibly diverse and... weird? They are truly fascinating as you get to DIG your way inside their subconscious minds to discover their true hidden feelings. Essentially, Schäfer came up with the idea of Inception before... well Inception. This is the unique part of the game - The environments, atmosphere and overall feel of the inner & deepest thoughts of the camp and local areas inhabitants's minds.Let me sum up some of the fascinating characters. We have a mad dentist who harvest brains, a talking fish whose thoughts involves a sequence where you become a giant Godzilla monster terrorizing a society of talking fish, a mentally ill security guard who's lost in the mindset of a crazy pyromaniac-milkman, Napoleon Bonaparte and his dimwit descendant, An aspiring musical starlet whose cruel mother's treatment of her and eventual suicide has caused her to develop a case of bipolar disorder, a government agent who disguises himself as a housewife by brandishing a rolling pin while talking disjointedly about pies etc. These are the kind of characters you can expect alongside the campers themselves and the local counselors, whom all are very well rounded and have their own personalities. Usually they are defined by interacting with them around the camp or examining the local signs and written letters, to provide character depth. Lastly, I found myself jamming to the game's cool blues-inspired guitar stringing soundtrack. All in all It's seemingly -- Well done. If you love a good platformer, with some dodgy gameplay at times, while every now and then laughing your♥♥♥♥♥off and maybe, just maybe, find yourself sympathizing with some of the loonies, as you uncover their hidden feelings. Then look no further than Psychonauts! :)

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Psychonauts is like a book with a weird cover. It's a game worth getting into though, even if your eyes might not agree with the art design. Once I got past my nitpicking, I finally gave it the shot it so very deserved. Psychonauts is a 3D platformer meets an adventure game and honestly, I had no idea about the former. As with all platformers, you'll die plenty from falling, which is partly due to a fixed camera and partly cos you suck. Then there are a couple of areas that just aren't very forgiving, but it's nothing you can't overcome. I'd say the difficulty level is just right for this sort of game, apart from the initally daunting and almost sadistic Meat Circus.It's funny, charming and fun to explore. Finding collectibles is made enjoyable, but you'll have to look out for a Point of No Return, otherwise you won't get 100%. The music from Milla's Dance Party is still in my head, a level that reminded me of the club mission in DmC Devil May Cry. I doubt Ninja Theory were influenced by Psychonauts, these games being such opposites, nevertheless I found it amusing.First Double Fine/Tim Schafer game now under my belt and I'll be checking out more from them. If it weren't for the massive development budgets we have right now, we'd see more cool games like these. Games like No One Lives Forever 3, which I'm still rooting for.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												So I picked up Psychonauts in 2016 for $1. People spoke pretty highly of this game, and I wanted something that could run on my laptop, so I got it. It took me about 20 hours to beat (longer than expected) and now that I have, I must say this game is absolutely brilliant. It's not perfect, it can be frustrating and the design isn't as polished as it could be, but I soon reached a point where I was so invested in the characters and storyline I was willing to put up with these blemishes in order to see things through.I'd like to start with the biggest strength of the game: the levels. In the game, you have to stop this sinister plot of lobotomies and kidnappings, and you do so by traveling into the minds of various people, often as a means of getting them to aid you. As such, most of the levels consist of navigating a specific mind, and each mind/level has its own unique aesthetics, mechanics, and tasks to complete. For instance, there's a level in here where you explore a mind that takes the form of a sprawling metropolis, and you play as a Godzilla-like monster that destroys it. The goal of this level is to destroy a tower in the center of the city, there are tanks and other anti-Godzilla weapons, and you get introduced to a shield, which you pretty much have learn to use to beat this level. There's another level where you encounter a mind that places you as a piece in board game. You have to talk to the other pieces (they have fun things to say), and deliver them food or money or munitions in order to deploy them and beat your opponent. This level involves some tricky platforming and light puzzle-solving, and I personally loved its aesthetic. A lot of these levels also feature their own boss/bosses, each of which is as unique as the environment they inhabit, and you'll have to figure out their vulnerabilities and how to exploit them.Since the levels are based on the minds of people you meet, you will encounter all sorts of interesting, complex people. I developed an emotional attachment to many of them which really gave me a sense of satisfaction in beating the various levels. For instance, you meet someone in anguish over a lost love, and it was so cathartic helping that character let go. And many of these characters are not all they seem. You may also punch, levitate, and attempt to ignite many of these characters to hear them make all sorts of indignant responses.I want to touch more on the gameplay. It's a third-person platformer from the PS2 era. Seems pretty bland, but they give you a whole slew of psychic powers and a diverse selection of enemies to use them on. I very much enjoyed the combat, though I wasn't much of a fan of the platforming. (This is partly because I'm not very good at platformers and because I played the whole game with a mouse an keyboard.) There were parts of the game where I'd jump, miss, and then get bumped back to the last checkpoint and have to do it over again. That being said, I feel like the game has enough checkpoint to not be too maddening or punishing. The game really gets difficult towards the end, make no mistake of that, but it's doable if you have the patience.Speaking of frustration, the game does have some annoying design issues. Remember, this is an old game. Because it's third person, sometimes the camera decides to jump behind a wall and you lose sight of your character. The game also gives you a lock-on tool to assist in aiming, and sometimes it doesn't recognize a target and points you in the opposite direction you wanted, and that causes you to miss your window of attack. And there are some glitches like where your character gets stuck, but you can normally jump around to free yourself. Again, if you have the patience, these aren't too damning.In conclusion, the game is clever in its world-building, characters, and gameplay, just remember that it's an old, tough platformer.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												This is easily my favourite Double Fine game, and that's saying a lot.At its core this is a third person action adventure platform title, but such a dry description really does not do it justice.It is happiness and nostalgia distilled into a quirky game about getting into people's minds, literally.No generic fire level, ice level, jungle level.Let's visits MINDS.The mind of a war veteran.The mind of a painter obsessed with bullfighting.The mind of a faded actress.THE MIND OF A SEA MONSTER.A great story, a great cast, a great WORLD created for you to explore and discover.Yes, the game has some balance issues, but most of these have been patched out for the Steam release (especially difficulty balancing in the last world).It's a great game that I totally recommend.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Be warned that this is an early-2000s 3d platformer and it really shows- annoying collect-a-thons and all. A controller is recommended if you have access to one- the keyboard controls work but can be a little wonky at times. Some very difficult platforming throughout brings these niggles to light and can be frustrating.Where Psychonauts shines instead is in the hugely imaginative (literally!) world and cast of characters, who play the role of both plot progression and game world. Raz's psychic abilities allow him to enter the minds of those who let him in, in order to arrange their thoughts and solve their problems for them- learning their secrets in the meanwhile. Battle Napoleon in a giant game of Risk, help the Milkman defeat the evil girl scouts, and maybe even help Raz confront his childhood fears. Erik Wolpaw, who would later join Valve to write the Portal and Team Fortress series, lends his talents to these characters and ensures they'll leave a big impression on you. If you can forgive the difficulties with the gameplay, the humour on display here is wholly worth it.

number of helpful: 22 of 24 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												First off I'm gonna tell you one thing, buy this game, and then I'll explain why you should. This game is absolutely fantastic. It's fun, it's got a great story, great characters, and hilarious (if not somewhat cheesy) dialogue.The story is quite interesting, but it's actually really enhanced by the characters. Double Fine did an excellent job of giving every single character (yes even the minor ones) a sense of actual human personality. A 10 year old boy who's running away from the circus to become a psychic agent, a sarcastic girl with the ability to talk to plants and takes no BS from anyone, a timid, socially awkward boy who was told to go to the camp because he kept blowing up people's heads with his mind, and a plethora more of quirky characters really make the game world and gameplay twice as fun and hilarious.However, another thing that Double Fine did that really gave the game some depth is the subtly. If you pay close attention to each character and their dialogue, memory vaults, and figments, you can find out some surprisingly....dark things about them. Even the main character, Razputin, mentions some pretty awful things that happened to him and his family as a child. But these little things add even more character to them, it makes them feel like they could be actual people because who hasn't had bad experiences or trauma in their lives? For a lot of the young campers, how they hint at these really tragic events is very child-like of them, like how an actual kid who can't quite comprehend those kinds of things would describe or talk about them.(You can see that I love the characters in this game right?)Moving on, the combat system is a boatload of fun, with cool abilities that are decently balanced with the gameplay. You can levitate and shoot psychic blasts of energy at your enemies, light almost every living thing on fire, and a bunch more cool things that are required to progress through different levels of the game. Speaking of the game levels, they're coloful and vary from each person's mind you enter, with different bosses and NPCs as well as the variety of different objects and missions that really tell you about the personality of the person's mentality.However, there does tend to be a bit of vagueness in certain levels where I'd get stuck because there was no clear objective or direction to what I was trying to do. At times it was more frustrating than other levels and if you've ever heard of the infamous last level of this game, the difficulty curve just spikes suddenly with how ridiculously hard and unforgiving it can be (and this version on Steam is the easier version of it!). But nonetheless, it kept me playing the game in a raging "I'm going to beat this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level so help me" kind of way.I will say if you're a person who goes for 100% completion or achievements, good luck to you. There's hundreds of these things in the game called figments (like figments of one's imagination) and in some levels they're placed in ridiculously hard to find places. I'm not a person who really cares for those things as much so it never bothered me, but I can definately see how it would irritate some people who either really hate collecting.But aside from those little nitpicks and some level frustrations, I absolutely adore this game (and am currently restarting it) and would reccommend it to as many people as possible so Double Fine can come out with a sequel for it already!

number of helpful: 19 of 19 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
Short version: 88%The cute (but dated) puzzle platformer surface of Psychonauts hides a game teeming with ideas, imagination, and great design choices (plus a not too great control scheme). A game that is worthy of all the praises it got in the past years.Long version:When Tim Schafer started his own company, Double Fine, in 2001, he was mostly known as the somewhat eccentric designer behind the greatest LucasArts adventures. So when their first title, Psychonauts, was finally released in 2005, it was a surprise to see it commercially fail despite the great reviews.Although the game eventually gained the following it deserves, it is easy to understand the initial troubles: on the surface, it looks like a typical early 2000s 3D puzzle platformer with 90s kids’ movie stereotype characters drawn as Nickelodeon figures. It took years to finally understand that its greatness lies under the hood.For starters, there is the plot. Initially, it seems like a summer camp movie about kids who have psychic powers, but as the story goes on, we learn that this movie was apparently directed by Tim Burton, as it slowly turns into a (kid-friendly) nightmare world for our brave protagonist, the somewhat clichéd sassy tough kid Rasputin.This change in atmosphere is anything but subtle, as the game world moves from a somewhat serene campground to a creepy island asylum. Both of these serve mostly as an overworld that ties together the actual levels, all set in the mindscape, the psyche of certain characters.These levels are the main reason behind the late-coming success of Psychonauts. Each offers something brand new game mechanic, ranging from simple platforming to almost point ‘n’ click levels of story-driven puzzle solving. They delve deep in the minds of a character, utilising this to its full extent to tell us an interesting, often bittersweet tale, showing us the full capabilities of the storywriting strength Double Fine could deliver.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												A decent 3D platformer for children aged 1 to 92. Psychonaut's strength is its charm - you play as Raz, a psychocadet, training to be a psychonaut. Psychonauts travel through others minds - an inception-like endeavor - often helping the individual reach some closure. Adults will appreciate the intricacies - you collect mind fragments, clear mind webs, and open emotional baggage. Every mind/level is unique, a reflection of the individual's personality with each introducing interesting mechanics. Honestly, I feel like Psychonauts is an interesting piece which tries to illustrate the uniqueness of the mind. It tries to get us to take another's perspectives - to, like Raz, explore their mind.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												Psychonauts is a 3D action-platformer game originally released on Xbox and Windows in 2005. This game is probably one of the most creative and artful games ever made. In this game, you are a character named Razputin and you need to travel through people's brains in order to solve their problems and whatnot. Each brain (world) is completely different and can be pretty weird. A world takes 30 minutes to 1 hour to complete most of the time, more if you're wasting your time somewhere or trying to solve a puzzle (yes, there are a few puzzles, but they aren't very difficult and give you hints all the time). The game itself isn't super long, you can finish it within 20 hours, probably around 5 if you're replaying the game (it took me 17 hours). You also get upgrades in your journey which let you use special powers (levitation, shooting fire, etc.)This game is gold. It has great writing and some bizarre humour, excellent voice acting, beautiful environments, good character design, and an awesome soundtrack. On the negative side, the camera can get annoying sometimes and the story continuity kinda drops near the end of the game. Other than that, it's a game that you should definitely try (you can also get in on Xbox Live or the new Mac version) and that is worth every penny. I honestly wish this game got a sequel though. Awesome game, totally recommend to absolutely anyone.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Many people describe this game as a "cult classic", but that does a disservice to a broadly appealing game that does so much right. Psychonauts, nearly a dozen years after release, remains an engaging and entertaining action-adventure 3d platformer that remains one of the funniest video games available. The graphics, while far from impressive by today's standards, have aged well because they focus on expressiveness rather than realism. The platforming, likewise, while plagued by occasional camera-angle issues, is perfectly decent.But the reasons you should play this game are the laughs and the level design. The theme of a psychic who leaps into the minds of others for each level is quite inventive, and unlike most games with inventive themes, this one backs it up with inventive gameplay. From the clean and tidy cube in the mind of the secret agent, to the twisted logic-and-gravity-defying mind of the schizophrenic, to many other hilarious worlds I hesitate to spoil but which introduce new mechanics, each level in Psychonauts feels like its own little masterwork. These are not just the same levels with new skins, or new enemies, each level in this game FEELS very different, and over a decade later I've yet to see a game with better level design.This is one of the true classics -- not just cult classics -- of PC gaming, and anyone who hasn't played it should certainly consider grabbing it during one of those times when it's on sale for a buck, such as today.

number of helpful: 19 of 20 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												Psychonauts is a third person action platformer made by Double Fine Productions following the psychic adventures in a summer camp for psychics training to be spies, as well as uncovering a camp-wide conspiracy involving psychic tanks, maniacal dentists, T.V., and milk.When I first started playing Psychonauts I was a bit dubious. A game with a cult-status which is supposedly impossible to dislike because of how stylish and funny it is--or so I was told by the legions of the internet--with a witty and incredible world populated with fun memorable characters. And milk.And It's with a strange feeling that I tell you that it's all of those things and even more. A game that genuinely impressed me even while riding on the backs of glowing reviews and flowery retrospectives. A game that made me laugh so hard that I actually had to put down the controller in order to recollect myself. A game that made me hungry yet again for things like color and style in video games, for things like inventive level design and meaningful story/level interaction, for things like interesting puzzles and fleshed out platforming. For things like milk.Delicious milk.Ignore all the praise, and meet this game on it's own terms. It's a fully realized adventure with charm and fun that makes you feel emotions of almost every spectrum even in it's modest playtime but never sacrifices gameplay or entertainment to make it's point. To say no to such an experience is absoultely brainless.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												Psychonauts truly surprised me.Having been recommended Psychonauts on a few occassions, I finally decided to give it a try. First off it has to be noted that the game is nearly a decade old, and one must remember that while dealing with the clunky graphics. But beyond that, the art style and general gameplay is wonderful. The game offers a classic platformer in a beautiful and unique visual style, that quickly goes from calm and peaceful to dark and gloomy. Initially the story starts off very much aimed towards children, but as the game progresses it becomes more about immaturity than childishness, and during certain parts of the game you might even find yourself wondering "Who is this game actually geared towards?!" (Spoilers: Madman stealing brains. Lots of kids burned to death. Suicidal/Sadistic/Murdering campmates. And more psychopathic nonsense.) The general story is humorous, surreal, cute, psychopathic, dark and immature, the tone of the game changes on a second's notice and takes you through dozens of surrealistic worlds, all with their unique charm and mood, much like the various characters you will meet throughout it. It is by far one of my all-time favorite Double-Fine games.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
What a rush of nostalgia. Psychonauts brought me back to my childhood. To be more specific the  era where 3D plaformers (with RPG elements) became the norm for videogames. It is a refreshing, quirky, amusing, and very satisfying game overall. It also strengthens the argument that great graphics are not necessary for games to be great.Positive:- Creative, original story- Quirky art-style that perfectly fits the game- Great voice-acting- Controls are responsive and feel natural- Plenty of silly jokes- Many unique levels/worlds which force you to think differently- Fantastic difficulty curve - the game gradually expects more out of you- The game feels fair. If you die it was probably your own fault- Plenty of side quests and collectables (adds to replay value)- Levitation = wheeeeeeNegative:- As expected of most 3D plaformers: camera angles can sometimes be terrible- The mechanism for rail grinding can be awkward- There is a lot of information thrown your way when you begin. It can be overwhelming for new gamers- Not always clear what you are expected to do- Where is Psychonauts 2?!Conclusion:Well? What are you waiting for. This game is a must for anyone who has fond memories of fantastic 3D platformers. With such a low price tag there really are no excuses (especially when it goes on sale: only 1 euro!). If you are concerned about the graphics, don't be. You will have such a great time that it won't even matter. After a while you will grow to appreciate the art-style.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Psychonauts has some outdated game design decisions (we are all immensely bored of collect-all-the-things), but this does not take away from the sheer depth and beauty of it as a platformer and a universe.The game Psychonauts has an intense dedication in immersing you in summer camp for psychics universe. You feel like the other children have their own quests and goals and you see them taking classes with you. It's little details like this that make Psychonauts stand out from other platformers that put all their focus in level design, and the bare minimum in immersion. On top of that, I am very impressed at the overarching theme of exploring the "typical mind fallacy" and in how we tend to overlook the experience and stories of children and those of different cognitive experiences. Early in the game, a child will tell a story that both the player and the teachers conclude is "just a story". Later in the game this "just a story" becomes a clear story point. And Raz is a delightful protagonist. I've never seen a game explore anxiety in its general and social forms so effectively. (I related a bit too strongly to the under-water level.)Despite various outdated game design mechanics, Psychonauts is a classic which should be played by all future game designers if only to learn how important a dedication to world immersion is and how much more satisfying a game mechanic is when it's intimately linked to story and theme.

												This game is a lot of fun, and despite being nearly 10 years old, it still holds up really well and plays great. Most of the game is fun and not frustrating (except for the second to last section of the entire game, right before the final boss; try not to punch your screen there ;) ). This may look like a kids game and may even be meant to be a kids game, but I think anyone of any age who enjoys gaming will have fun with this. The only negatives are mainly due to its age: low resolution cut-scenes are ugly, yeah the graphics and character models are a bit blocky, the invisible walls you encounter don't seem to conform to the shape of the environment, etc. And that second to last bit of the final level just before the final boss will be an exercise in frustration and anger management. But really, none of these things are bad enough to be a dealbreaker in this game. Worth getting at its usual price; absolute no-brainer when on sale. :)

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												I had this in my library for over a year and a half before I finally finished it. I regret to not have done so much earlier, because this is truely an outstanding game. I'm really envious of the amount of creativity. There are so many details and humorous easter eggs. It's pretty lengthy as well. Much content. Lots of good!What makes this game special first and foremost is the jarring design - that makes the characters, the voices, the dialogue, the level architecture + gimmicks and naturally the humour. What I like about it is, that it takes itself serious enough to not become a total joke. It's not constantly funny and that's a good thing.I also like the structure and all the little conveniences. You have a Hub-world with multiple screens where you can free-roam to collect goodies. You have a transit system for fast travel and can get information at every moment so you never have to leave the game if you're stuck. The actual levels are in people's mind, and boy, did they make sure everyone feels unique. They are thinking out of the box more that in the box if you know what I mean. There is also a level select screen, the collective unconscious - another means to give you quick and easy control over where to go.Psychonauts is a blend of different genres. It's a 3D-Platformer but also an Action-Adventure game. These elements are served in rotation and there are long stretches where one of these takes a backseat. For example, sometimes you are significantly jumping around more and collecting stuff, Other times it's more about item management and problem solving and then there is straight-out combat. Very good pacing, both gameplay-wise and visually.And there is a lot to do... the feature list of the game mechanics are staggering. It could be tedious at some point or the other to collect all figments, say like 243 in a huge screen, but most of the time it feels very good to get everything. In some places it is a little glitchy and frustrating. You eventually get annoyed in your attempt to conquer all of it. Like, when you set the enemy on fire and he runs into you and passes in on, making you run around uncontrollably. Or when you can't get enough momentum to jump high enough off off a trampoline. Or when you're trapped in a tight space and jiggle around to get free. Yeah... be prepared for this. At that point you're probably willing to forgive more easily when the game has won you over.A little tip to prevent you from having the same start as me: As soon as you reach level 3 (from 10) you get a new mode of transport and that changes everything.Play with a gamepad!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												First time review, so here it goes:This is a great game. No caveats or buts; it is, without question, a masterpiece.The games is about a young boy named Raz, who ran away from the circus to a summer camp to become a Psychonaut.Once there he meets many quirky and colorful characters and enters their minds to fight their inner-demons, unpack their emotional baggage, and maybe learn to set things on fire.The main strength of this title comes from its focused design. All the pieces just fit well together. The level of minds you must face, the leveling system, the odd off the wall plot, the aft for mentioned cast of characters, the music choices, and the overall sense of the game. A mix of the seemingly familiar wrapped in the trapping of the strange.Some very minor nitpicks I feel I need to add. They are by no means game breakers. In fact I encourage you to go play this game before reading this list. The game doesn't tell you can interact with as many things as you actually can. For my second play through I was using the action button on everything and finding that there's always some throwaway line or gag for nearly every object or person. The figments (one of your main collectables) are the fiddliest things to get in every level. They can range from mildly annoying, frustrating (the race), to downright impossible (waterloo world). That wouldn't be so bad if there was a way you could track down the ones you missed (you always miss one, guaranteed). But if you really want 101% you need to use the internet to track down the missing ones (itself a pain in the butt). I honestly had no problem with the Meat Circus first or second time. (The first time I did have problems with (one of) the final boss, but that was performance issues with my PC and me not configuring it properly). [Pro-tip: ignore everything in the first tent and just save the little kid and get to the top. You can come back later]One last thing I want to really highlight, is the settings of the levels. Every one of which is exploding with a creativity rarely seen in any videogame. My favorite is a toss-up between Waterloo World and The Milkman Conspiracy. (Though Lungfishoppolis comes in a close third)In the end, this is only my opinion, not everyone’s. I mean, what do you care, this game is how old now and every person on the internet has given their opinion on everything. But hear me out, even as old as it is, it is still one of the greatest video games of all time. Period. The humor, the charm, it's all there for all to see and play. The sequel is apparently coming out soon, I don't know what to think about that, but if it is half as good as the original the gaming world on the whole will be better for it. Signing off in the words of Coach Oleander that I think sum up the game quite nicely- "You shall engage the enemy in his own mentality! You shall chase his dreams! You shall fight his demons! You shall live his nightmares. And those of you who fight well, you will find yourselves on the path to becoming international secret agents — in other words... Psychonauts! The rest of you... will die!"

content:
Posted: April 10
 Psychonauts  8/10If you liked: Banjo Kazooie, Super Mario 64, Conker's Bad Fur Day, Earthworm Jim GameplayPros:-The abilities you acquire make platforming fun-Platforming isn't needlessly challenging besides the final level-Collecting certain items unlocks backstories of the game's characters, making the collect-a-thon fun-Rare to get stuck on a section thanks to in-game assistance.Cons: -The platforming is sort of floaty in the same vein as Banjo Kazooie. This personally doesn't bother me but I know for some platforming enthusiasts it's a problem. -The combat is rough, think Zelda z-targeting. However, it's fairly uncommon. -Some abilities aren't really useful outside of the area you unlock them in. Classic Zelda-itis. -Collect-a-thon's aren't for everybody. I didn't 100% the game. (yet?)Graphics:Pros: -Artstyle is clean and interesting-Most of the models still look nice for a PS2 era gameCons: -The game has obviously aged, it was released in 2005-The artstyle may not be for everybody. It's best described as "grotesque." Reminiscent of early 90s cartoons (Ahh! Real Monsters, Ren & Stimpy, etc.. Personally it took a few hours to grow on me, afterwards I'm fond of it.)Writing:Pros: -The writing is unexpectedly funny, don't miss the conversations with all the NPCs. This is really the main draw of the game. -All main characters have interesting/tragic backstories that flesh them out well-The game is a good length. I finished the story at 11 hours in. That'd probably stretch out to 15-16 hours with 100% completion. Cons: -The game is really slow at the start. The first 3 levels (comprising about 30% of the game) are tutorials. The first especially is really rough. Push through and the game finds its stride quickly. Technical Trouble/Misc:-The mouse/keyboard controls are truly terrible. Do yourself a favor and play with a controller. -The camera causes some problems towards the end-game-The game should run fine on any computer from this decade. However, evidently there are some issues with AMD cards where effects don't appear properly. -Buy the Dowsing Rod in the shop ASAP. It finds 40-50 arrowheads at a time instead of one. -This is a 3d platformer in the same vein as the games I mentioned at the outset. If you didn't like those, you probably won't like this. Overall, Psychonauts is a hilarious, silly game with solid platforming. Anyone who plays it is left with a charming, memorable experience. 8/10**If you like/love any of the games at the top of this review, pick this up ASAP**

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
TL;DRBUY THIS GAME! If you have a controller, I'd recommend it over the keyboard and mouse as I've found it to be much easier to control Raz with a controller instead of the keyboard.Over a decade and the game still holds up.Psychonauts is truly a testament to great game design — released over a decade ago and still holds up well. The game features one of the most original stories this side of Spec Ops: The Line, and the humor is on-point though subtle. The characters are unique, and most importantly, human. Each one has their own problems, motivations and quirks. As the story progresses, you'll get to see characters' lives unfold, each one a different arc. I think the true achievement of Psychonaut's storytelling is that you, the protaganist, is never the main character of the story, but simply a conduit. Your actions move the story forward, but it's the lives of others that draw your attention and empathy.And my god, the level design. Instead of filling the game with gimmicky tricks that are used once (and never again, I'm looking at you Assassin's Creed, Bioshock, Dishonored, etc.), the levels in Psychonauts is designed in such a way that each ability will undoubtedly be used over and over again (except for Clairvoyence). The levels also do not feel repetitive. Even though the core mechanics never change from the first mission to the last, every mission has it's own little gimmick that makes that one particular level feel different than every other level.The soundtrack is on point, and even though the graphics undoubtedly feel a bit dated, when a game is this good, it doesn't really matter.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2013
												One of the most unique and hilarious platformers I have ever played, Psychonauts carries on the Double Fine legacy with near perfect form. The story of Raz and his adventure in a camp for psychics is both charming and at times extremely disturbing, but from beginning to end you can really tell just how much the writers poured their hearts into each and every line.The gameplay isn't as original, falling in line with most other platformers in terms of mechanics, though the controls do leave a bit to be desired. The levels on the other hand are some of the most bizarre and interesting I've seen in any game, a few harkening back to Double Fine's adventure game roots with some clever puzzles to mix things up.Everything is brought together with a fantastic art direction. If Tim Burton and Pixar had a lovechild, it would look like Psychonauts. The music is memorable, the voice acting top notch, and overall it is simply a marvelous game that I can recommend to any fan of Double Fine or just 3D platformers in general!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												The good -- A funny, original story with good voice acting and genuinely funny dialogue throughout. Can be childish at times, but it fits with the humor and juxtaposes well with some of the darker and more mature elements.- Great art direction, despite its age the graphics still don't look dated and fit with the look and feel of the game perfectly. The character design tends more towards cartoony characters whose appearance give you a good outline of their personality, and the environments vary widely from traditional platformer areas to mind bending levels that twist and turn through every axis.- Tight platformer mechanics, moving around and exploring the environments is easy and encouraged thanks to loads of hidden collectables. Its easy to keep track of your progress, and constantly unlocking something new, or being just about to, will keep you playing that one more level.The bad -- Occasional problems with the camera, the usual having to wrestle it under control from a preset position. Part and parcel of 3D platformers ported from consoles.- Some of the latter levels have some downright unfair sections with long runs between checkpoints and unforgiving level design that can become quite frustrating.- Optimization problems with Windows 7. There are loads of threads all over the net complaining of crashes and freeze-ups, which seem to only occur on Windows 7. True, running the game in compatibility mode (I used Windows 95) solves this issue but it seems like a glaring problem for a game on Steam, no matter how old.Personal Highlights (contains level spoilers, no storyline spoilers) -- Lungfishopolis - Destroying a city populated by fish as a giant Kaiju Theatre version of yourself. Complete with gameplay being interrupted by news flashes as the fish report on your rampage of destruction.- The Milkman Conspiracy - One of the most head bending levels I've seen in a platformer in recent times.- Razputin (the main character) is voiced brilliantly by Richard Horvitz (the voice of Invader Zim). YMMV on this one, but as a fan of the show I loved hearing the distinctive voice throughout.Summary -Won't be everyone's cup of tea, but if you like platformers and adventure games, Psychonauts is an excellent example of an original and unique take on the genre. It's fun to play, memorable in both its level design and its story, and, frankly, there's not much out there (especially recently) that compares to it. Let down by minor problems that plague many console to PC ports, but they don't hamper it enough to be a standout game.9/10Context - 9Challenge - 8Catharsis - 8

content:
Posted: January 7, 2013
												Wow! Where to begin, this game is just so incredible and so mind blowing that it's a real damn shame this is dubbed by many as "the best game you never heard of". This game is heavily underrated but yet it has a strong cult following. This is from the genius mind that brought us such great classics as the Monkey Island series and the ever popular PC hit Grim Fandango comes Tim Schafer's greatest creation since Brutal Legend, Psychonauts. This game has his style written all over it from the comedic story to the well balanced game play. It looks and sounds like something out of the mind of Tim Burton from the design to the music.Psychonauts is a single player experience with a well written story and tells it in a very comedic style that left me laughing throughout the entire game. You play a young boy named Raz who just arrived at camp for psychics and you experience the misadventures he goes through at his time there. Not one character is one dimensional and playing through this game you don't see that in other games. I really appreciated that and what they did with everything in the game. This is possibility the best platformer or let alone the best game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. In no way was the game hard nor was it a push over. It is well balanced and a great pick up for veteran gamers or new comers alike.I played this game on the original Xbox when it came out and playing it again reminded me how great this game is. This is my second time playing it and my first time playing it on PC. I have to say that the PC version of the game is much much better and it really shows. The graphics on it are much clearer and sharper than on console. And since this is the Steam version of the game, they added Achievements to boot. If you played it already on console, weither is was on the PS2 or Xbox, this is your second chance to play it all over again. My only gripe with the port is that the cut scenes were not optimized for PC, but that doesn't matter. It's a very good game and that is all that matters. :DI highly recommened this game for every gamer out there. This game is a solid 10/10

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This is probably the textbook definition of a "hidden gem." In terms of story and atmosphere, the game has a level of demented charm that you really don't see a lot of any more in games, movies, or cartoons nowadays. Most of the time I found myself grinning or even laughing at some of the things the characters said. Every environment is filled with personality. Thinking about it now, the level of character that the developers have put into the game reminds me of games like Earthbound.In terms of gameplay, it's a solid 3d platformer. At first you may think that it's just another platformer, which in itself isn't a bad thing, but at the same time maybe you were wanting more. I promise, if you stick with the game, it becomes a different beast with the more psychic powers you obtain. I recommend a controller for the game, but it's still playable with a keyboard and mouse. Overall, it's a fantastic game. Aside from the short length of the game and a few audio and graphical hiccups here and there, I didn't have that many issues with it, and it's definitely worth the $10 price.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I recommend this game tentatively. Pros: - Beautiful and Unique Art Style. It reminds me a bit of Invader Zim, but not so much so that I'd declare it a plain rip off. - Intricate and Masterful storytelling. The plot is interesting and keeps me coming back for more. I'm never just slogging through something hoping for a payoff. It's all a genuinely fun story.- Likable characters. Even the characters who barely get screen time or have no lines seem to be overflowing with personality. They feel very real, despite being so stylized. - Fun game mechanics. The psychic abilities are endlessly fun. Levitation is my absolute favorite, mainly because it frees up the movement of your character a lot, but there are several other abilities I really love. On top of being fun, they're necessary. Once a mechanic is introduced, they always give you a reason to use it. While you may eventually stop using it as often, it'll always come back a few more times.- Dialogue is witty and hilarious. It's not forced comedy like I see a lot of comedy games try to do. It's just funny, in a really natural way, and I found myself actually laughing out loud. Even jokes that fall flat were meant to do so, because the fact that the joke wasn't funny is part of the joke itself.- The vaults are probably my favorite part of the game. They're a sort of slide show deal, and there are usually two in every level. They're in depth explanations of certain points of that character's life, and they're a joy every time. - Bosses are challenging, but not impossible. They're all unique and just so fun. Cons: - The technology is from the PS2 era, and it shows. Some of the graphics are painfully outdated, and the pitful camera movement is a relic. You have to control the camera movement separately with your mouse, and it can tend to get frustrating during intense fights, trying to control the camera, move your character and target enemies. - Strange difficulty curve. The entire first section of the game is tutorials (understandably, considering the huge assortment of psychic abilities and mechanics they're trying to introduce) and at some point in the second half it suddenly jumps up to being extremely hard. I had to resort to a few lets plays at some parts because it was just so obtuse what you were supposed to be doing.- Figments and arrowheads were ridiculously annoying. Figments are somewhat transparent, so they tend to blend into the highly stylized backgrounds, making it almost impossible to know where they are at times. As for the arrowheads, they're practically everywhere, but at times the game demands you actively dig them up which just wasn't fun at all.- CRASHING. Good god, the crashing. At time of writing, the game has crashed at least 4 or 5 times today, which is why I'm writing this review now, hoping if I let it throw it's little tantrum for about half an hour it'll decide to work so I can continue playing. Perhaps it's just the computer I'm running it on (It's not really a gaming PC, but it is a high powered Mac) but it takes something away from the game when I'm saving every two steps in case the game decides to suddenly freeze and crash. Overall, I recommend it to anyone who wants to try something entirely new and different. It's a purely fun experience with a few technical issues that tend to drag it down at points. Despite the crashing and a few nit picky issues, I will continue playing it because I'm so invested, but if you don't think you could handle that, or don't have the patience for such a thing, I'd only recommend buying it on sale.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Psychonauts is one of those games that you overlook because of it's age. I heard nothing but good things about it but I still was not convinced. One day I decided, why not? and I never looked back... ok I looked back like 30 hours later and a few times inbetween asking myself what I'm doing with my life but that's not relevant to this review. So first off, this is a 3d action-adventure platformer with a light, fun and whacky art direction, everything about this game gives of a facade of humorus dialogue and ridiculous characters, but the underlying tale has a much darker theme going, telling the sad story of dissapointment and faliure, manifesting in insane and unstable human-beings given the shortest straw in life, this is a story about untangeling and getting to the core issue of one's mind and finding ways to overcome those issues.This game shows empathy and heart, it's funny, selfaware and it feels like every nook and crany in this game holds some sort of meaning, it's packed with collectibles and there is always something to do, I pretty much binged this game untill I had collected everything, not something I normally find compelling but this game somehow manages to keep my monkey-mind on track and for that it's easily one of the best games I've played so far, can't wait for the second Psychonauts.

												One of my personal favourite 3D platformers! It's got sweet as powers, from running around on a levitation ball, to picking objects up with telekinesis, or even shooting psychic energy! Posted: July 28, 2016
												This game is one hell of a trip.Like, it starts off decently normal, where you're in a strange world, at a camp. And you think to yourself, "Huh, well this is an interesting game, sort of weird but oddly addicting too." You expect it to be like other games that you have played. Then all of a sudden, as you continue playing, it just gets weirder and weirder, until you finally except that either you, the game, or both are insane somehow.You delve into the mind of multiple characters, learning about them, and conquering their fears or "inner demons", freeing them from a bigger problem.And along the way, you grow pretty attached to the main character of the story. And at the end you just sit back, staring at the main menu of the game, silently saying to yourself, "What the hell just happened?"11/10 would play again.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												A game with a incredibly unique concept on the platforming genre, Psychonauts is probably one of my new favorite platformers ever. You take the place of Rasputin (which I hoped was going to be the russian leader, but whatever) who has a mysterious past that I will not spoil, as you learn about it as you go on. You end up into a camp for "psychics," and unlike the other psychics, these guys are the real deal. You battle enemies by not just fighting them up front, but by going into their mind and fighting their demons. I can't wait to play more, as even the tutorial level is genius, with a general with a mind full of a whole boot camp. I never did play this game when it was released, but these graphics are still hold up very well, and the voice acting is amazing, especially the general of the camp. The only voice that was a little annoying was Rasputin's, but that might just be a personal preference. The gameplay is fun, and made me wanted to explore around the world the most I could to collect arrowheads, almost like a Banjo Kazooie game. In fact, the entire game reminds me of a remix on Banjo Kazooie, which, now that I think about it, is genius.All in all: with the sale for it being only 2 dollars, it is an absolute buy.Rating: 9.7/10

content:
Posted: March 5
												Do you remember that feeling of mystery and adventure that hit you back in the days, when you took up a new game? I mean those almost new 3D adventure games with sharp shapes, a mind blowing story and infinite secrets. Oh my, how I miss those games. The were the first I played with on console and PC, and they still hold a special place in my memories. They had always original ideas, not like some everlasting sequence of sequels of today; and nobody explained to you anything (except for a basic commands tutorial), you had to figure out everything by yourself, with curiosity and intelligence, and this made the winning so satisfying. And why am I acting like an old nostalgic gamer? Because Psychonauts is such a game, and I waited way too much to play it. It showed me how much games have changed over the years, for the best and for the worst, and how much we can learn from the masterpieces of the past to craft majestic titles in our future.Now, at the end of this (first) adventure in the Psyconauts Summer Camp, I am sincerely moved, by a game that reminded me why I started to play videogames when I was a boy, and why I still play them as a man.Vi ricordate  quella sensazione di mistero e aventura che vi prendeva quando iniziavate un nuovo gioco anni fa? Mi riferisco a quei giochi di avventura in 3D, ai tempi praticamente nuovi,  con le forme aguzze, una storia incredibile e segreti infiniti. Dio, quanto mi mancano quei giochi. Sono stati i primi a cui ho giocato su console e su pc, e occupano ancora oggi un posto speciale nei miei ricordi. Avevano sempre idee originali, non come certe infinite serie di sequel di oggi; e nessuno ti spiegava nulla (se non per un tutorial sui comandi base), dovevi capire tutto da solo, con curiosità e intelligenza, e questo rendeva la vittoria molto più soddisfacente.E perché mi sto comportando come un nostalgico vecchio gamer? Perchè Psychonauts è un gioco come quelli, e ho aspettato decisamente troppo per  giocarci. Mi ha mostrato quanto i videogiochi siano cambiati in questi anni, per in meglio e in peggio, e quanto possiamo imparare dai capolavori del passato per creare titoli meravigliosi in futuro.Ora, alla fine di questa (prima) avventura al Campo Estivo per Psychonauts, sono sinceramente commosso, da un gioco che mi ha ricordato perché ho iniziato a giocare ai videogiochi da bambino, e perché ci gioco ancora da adulto.
