content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer, but it still delivers an experience that feels wholly original in every aspect of its execution.Psychonauts is a quirky, offbeat game set in a special summer camp for clairvoyant kids, in which a group of psychic children end up in a wacky adventure filled with brain-stealing hijinks, psychic secret agents, and a little romance on top of everything else. It's rooted in the sorts of 3D platforming sensibilities we've all come to know over the years. But there's a SPIN to the game--its psychic theme--which adds some cool puzzle-solving to the usual platform-jumping and swinging associated with the genre. Psychonauts also bears the unmistakable mark of designer Tim Schafer (known for classic adventure games Grim Fandango, Full Throttle, and Day of the Tentacle), thanks to a hilarious array of peculiar characters and a story that never fails to entertain. Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer, but it still delivers an experience that feels wholly original in every aspect of its execution.It took four years and two publishers, but Psychonauts is finally here, and no worse for the wear, it seems.The heart and soul of Psychonauts is Razputin--or, Raz, for short--a big-headed, goggle-sporting psychic prodigy who sneaks his way into a mysterious summer camp that happens to be a training ground for the titular psychonauts, a group of psychic secret agents. Raz, it seems, has run away from his home in the circus and wants to become a psychonaut himself. Grudgingly, the counselors of the camp accept Raz into the group (albeit only for a day, until his father can come get him and take him home). However, it doesn't take long for strange things to start happening around camp. Raz, as well as other children, find that they're suffering from similar nightmares. Strange psychic interference seems to be POPPING UP all over the place, and not long after that, the brains of the other campers start disappearing, leaving the campers as soulless, TV-obsessed husks. As the hero of the story, Raz is on a mission to solve these various mysteries and uncover the crazy conspiracy behind it all.The basic plot itself reads like typical platformer fodder, but there's a lot more to Psychonauts' story than can be summed up in a single paragraph. This is largely due to the game's bizarre cast of characters, of which there are many. Raz himself is a highly likable hero; he's cute, heroic, funny, and also a little awkward at times. He fits the bill of the overenthusiastic yet not-quite-ready hero to the letter and it's hard not to feel sympathetic to his plight. But beyond Raz, there's a great supporting cast, with roughly two dozen other characters who play parts both large and small in the story. The counselors consist of Coach Oleander, an overly aggressive drill sergeant; Milla Vodello, a somewhat ditzy and party-happy go-go girl; Agent Nein, a pale-skinned, sweater-sporting scientist of indeterminate Eastern European origin; and Ford Cruller, a mysterious old man who seems to exist in about eight different places at once. These counselors join the crazy array of campers, as well as other strange people and creatures you'll encounter, to drive the storyline, and thanks to the game's excellent design, you'll have no shortage of opportunities to get ATTACHED to them.Initially, Psychonauts feels like a very open-ended game, especially because upon your first venture into the camp area, you'll find yourself able to just wander around, chatting it up with other campers or even just listening in on their completely INSANE conversations. The camp and its many areas make up a hub world, where you can access lots of different things, including a camp store, where you can buy helpful items, an underground tram that cuts down on backtracking, and all sorts of little hidden areas that yield bonus items. However, the biggest boon for the camp world is all the little bouts of dialogue you can discover. Depending on what stage of the game you're at, the conversations change up quite a bit, meaning you're not often going to hear a lot of repeats. This is great, especially because there's just so much of the dialogue. In some instances, you can literally just stand next to a pair of characters while they converse for about five minutes or longer and never hear the same line twice. And it's almost always really funny stuff.However, the most interesting aspects of Psychonauts' characters don't come from their real-world conversations, but rather from their internal monologue. As Psychonauts revolves around a bunch of psychics, the bulk of your time will be spent traversing the perils of people's minds. This is where Psychonauts truly shines. You'll be able to enter the minds of more than a dozen different characters in the game, and each mind serves as one of its main levels. Each level is completely unique. For instance, when you enter the head of Coach Oleander, you'll find a war-torn landscape filled with constant explosions, plants made out of ammunition, and, for reasons not immediately apparent, lots and lots of meat. In another example, you enter the mind of a crazed security guard named Boyd Cooper, who is utterly obsessed with nonsensical conspiracies and someone called "The Milkman." His mental landscape looks like a 1950s-era suburban neighborhood that's been picked up by a pair of hands, twisted into a topsy-turvy fun house, and occupied exclusively by shadowy agents in TRENCH COATS who try to convince you that they're just simple street workers, or hedge trimmers, or grieving widows, despite their obviously ulterior motives. It's all totally weird, but also undeniably unique.No two minds are exactly alike in Psychonauts, both aesthetically and in terms of gameplay. Granted, you will be spending at least some of YOUR time in each level engaging in the usual platforming shenanigans, like jumping and double-jumping over platforms, swinging from poles, walking tightropes, and so on. When the game is in full-on platformer mode, it plays very well. The controls are tight, the camera is rarely ever a problem, and it's generally pretty easy to get Raz around without screwing up, at least on the Xbox. The PC version controls well enough too, provided of course you have a good USB controller, as the keyboard and mouse controls just don't feel right for this type of game (and even with a USB controller, camera control can be a bit of a pain). If there's any one criticism to be mounted here across both platforms, it's that the game is rarely ever that difficult, save for a few specific parts that are actually quite tough. You can't call the game a total breeze, either, but most experienced players shouldn't have any problems mastering the basic play mechanics pretty quickly.The inside of a person's mind can be a pretty crazy place.Even though the game isn't particularly hard, at least it's not repetitive. The goals and challenges of each level are totally exclusive. In one level, you'll find yourself playing a bizarre board game against a mental projection of Napoleon Bonaparte. You'll shrink down to "fun size" to recruit new pieces to YOUR cause, and then you'll return to your normal size so that you can move them around. In another level, you're fighting neon-tinted luchadores and a big, hulking bull in what looks like a velvet painting of a congested Spanish city. It's with this kind of variety that Psychonauts manages to achieve its high level of quality.It also helps that the game has more to it than just a lot of jumping around. There are puzzles to be solved in Psychonauts, as well as battles to be fought, and both require use of Raz's list of crazy psychic powers. You start out only with a basic melee attack at your disposal, but as you play and collect items scattered about both the real world and mental worlds, you'll be able to upgrade Raz's rank and earn new powers, like telekinesis. 84/100

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												This sure is a great game, one of the lastest masterpieces coming from Tim Schafer.It's really sad it's really underrated in some points or in general.Why is this so great, you say? (or not, i'm going to say it anyways), it's totally fun, and really really creative, its fun to play and to progress, funny dialogues, bizarre moments and characters, sometimes you'll get some sad backstory coming from every character.Also, to keep in mind this: It's not a kids game. Neither +5, neither +10 or +13, despite the art, it has a lot of humour and dialogues that can be only taken serious or get a pun from the game if you're Teen/Adult, sure, a kid can play the game, but only to play, and follow some cliché things from every story of this kind.Now like every game, there is no perfection whatsoever. By this i mean, there are some bugs or mechanisms that are quite annoying in some point in the gameplay, sometimes you'll fall down, sometimes you won't grab a ledge, usually you'll touch A LOT of invisible walls, and there are some puzzles that are quite overthinked, or the only way to get the puzzle right it's going with the trial-n-error method, WHICH can take a lot of time and it will turn to be a bit boring, but once you get that right you'll feel really good.Characters are sure as hell NOT forgettable, they are distinguishable and special, really creative ways to play and make a nice but simple plot.In terms of port, you'll suffer some FPS drops in the mean time but they are really random, unless, of course, you use a FPS-locker program, because it lacks of FPS lock, so you will probably get 40 fps and then 80 fps but then 20 fps.Also, one more thing, it also lacks of controller support, but thanks to the internet, you'll get that done boy, with this guide

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												With the new Psychonauts game on the way, I felt I needed to make a review for the first one. Let me start off by saying that if you have not already played this game, you are missing out. It is an absolute classic from one of my favorite developers, Double Fine. (And the man behind it all: Tim Schafer)The game itself is filled with great humor, amazing level design, eccentric characters, a villain's ridiculous plot to take over the world, and a mysterious milkman. (Play the game to see what I am talking about) The creativity of the developers is astounding and I found myself actually wanting to come back to all the levels to collect every little thing the developers put in there. All the levels have their own charm to them and the premise of the game really allows for some of the most memorable levels I have ever had the joy to play through. And honestly, I am extremely excited now that we are finally going to get a continuation of the story in the new game they are developing. I really hope it will be good, but even if it isn't, I still think people should pick this game up and play through it. In my opinion, it is well worth the $10 asking price, but if you still don't want to pay that much, then make a note to pick it up during a sale. Pros- Great Characters- Humorous story- Amazing levels- Interesting premise- Psychic Powers- MilkmanCons- Collecting all the figments can be annoying sometimes. (Only a problem for completionists)- Some minor bugs- It ends. :(Overall, I highly recommend this game. It's worth the price and Double Fine really produced a great game. Personal Score: 9/10

content:
Posted: February 25, 2013
												Double Fine make some really good games, this being one of the best in my opinion, the trailer for this game really doesn’t do it justice and I’ve noticed that in a few double fine games to be honest. They don't usually show off the game for what it really is, nor show its true potential. Just from the trailer, I didn't think this was something I would ever play, but I got it in a bundle and it’s actually an amazing game.Like any good game, some parts can be frustrating, but it’s all part of the fun. Because it wasn’t the kind of frustration for me that made me want to give up, more so the kind you want to keep trying again, and then when you do succeed, you feel like you've accomplished something. The story is quite quirky and fun, the dialog can be really humorous at times as well, at least to me. You can definitely tell the creative team of double fine are behind it, there is fun characters to interact with and fun little stories to unfold behind each one. Also, there is a lot of collectables and little Easter eggs to find in the game. It’s not one of those games that it seems like a chore to do, for me it was actually fun. But then again, I do like my collectables in games.All in all, I think it’s an amazing game, it’s definitely worth buying, if I didn't get it in a bundle, I would very happily of spent the money on it knowing now how good it is. I even liked it so much as to go back after my first play through and complete it 100%, achievements and all. Which took around 2 and a half playthroughs, it was a lot of fun. Even though I’ve finished it, I can still see myself going back and playing it again in the future. It’s a very enjoyable game, and I’m glad that I did end up playing it, despite what the trailer made me originally think.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Such an imaginative concept that's explored so well. A lot of variety in the gameplay, with radically different scenarios and many powers and types of movements you can use. Hilarious dialogue, charming characters, so much attention to detail (every NPC has dozens and sometimes hundreds of responses and the artistry of some of the locations is astonishing), and lots of collectibles which you are well rewarded for. Clearly made with a lot of love, and you'll fall in love with it too.Runs well even on an old PC. There are a few moments where the platforming can get tricky, but the whole game can be done even on a keyboard. Even if you don't care for platformers, make an exception for this one, because this game gives you so much.

												This is what I think can be called a modern day classic game. The world the game creates feels like something that they really put a lot of thought into with characters that absolutely fit in and interact in charming and very interesting ways. When I remember this game, I remember it in the same way I do a good movie or book. It has that strong of a unifying theme and directed narrative experience, except you can actually play it. The gameplay and mechanics are some of the least memorable parts of this to me because they just feel so natural to the story they're going for. And I think of that as a good thing.

Posted: April 2, 2016
												There's a reason why Psychonauts is in my top 10 favorite games of all timePositives-Unique presentation-Fantastic controls-Brilliant level design -Well written characters, I only wish some were given more spotlight, like Boyd Cooper and Sasha Nine.-An engaging storyNegitives-There was a lot of noticeable pace breaks during a play though,  namely when you get to the Insane Asylum and you have to go though 4 different minds without any real story going on. Also when you are in Rasputin's mind and you have to go to the top of the tower and then all of a sudin you need to get your levitation power.-Near the end of the game, there's no way to go back to the hub world, so if you wanted to go back and get everything to get rank 101, you'll have to start the game all over again.Overall Psychonauts is a fantastic game 9.5/10

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Psychonauts is honestly my favorite game - you really can't find games like this anymore. The humor is woven into the game, the characters are so intricate and likeable, and the story is entirely it's own and executed so well. The worlds you explore in this game are all so distinctly their own and creatively made. You can tell that lots of love and work got put into this project, and it has that 2000's feel that gets the nostalgia going. I will admit that at times the controls and camera can be more of a frustration than a feature, but for most of the game they work just fine. Achievement hunters should go into the game wary, as finding every figment is beyong annoying and the only aspect of this game that has ever actually frustrated me. If you can get past those couple little things, though, this game is so genuine and not afraid to be itself that it's well worth the time and money.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2012
												It has action, humor, and an enthralling story. It's an adventure game like no other featuring children soldiers. It's none other than Psychonauts. You play as Razputin, or Raz for short, who has a dream to become a Psychonaut, a psychic soldier who protects to the world,  before his parents can pick him up from Psychonaut training camp. As he ventures through the camp grounds completing task for his councilors, he stumbles upon something that could mean the end of the world. Through many obstacles and enemies, you must find a way to stop this calamity from happening all before you are picked up from camp. A game of this stature deserves much more praise than what it has received. Tim Schafer did an excellent job on creating a spell bounding game that captures your interest within seconds. A cult-classic in gaming that needs to be played.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												I'm just gonna go ahead and call this game a "classic", "must-play".So, the idea is your character has different 'psychic' powers. The most basic one is double-jumping, and you gradually learn many other ones (some examples are shooting, moving stuff with your mind, burning stuff, seeing things how others' see them). They are complemented with various items, gadgets. All these are used in battle, but, more importantly, for solving puzzles, which will surprise you with their originality. If you pay attention, you will notice hints subtly hidden in what the characters say. And if you need more help, you can always call your scizophrenic mentor using a piece of bacon... yeah.There is also a lot of acrobatics involved. Jumping, floating, various interactions with platforms, poles, ropes, ledges, etc.A lot of stuff is frankly weird (and may creep you out if you're very sensitive), because often the action takes place inside other characters' imagination (many of them crazy, like in the asylum where you help the patients overcome their problems). Sometimes space/gravity is bent, which is also a nice addition to gameplay.All the levels are different and unique in some way.The story takes about 15 hours. And that's the minimal amount of time you will need to complete it (at least if you're not intentionally going as quick as possible). There is tons of content. Because there is a concept similar to "experience" and "levels" (which only let you unlock more powers - nothing like the usual RPGs), you can go at your own pace and complete as many side quests (which are usually tied to exploration of the game world) as you want. There is almost no grinding involved.★★★★★★★★★☆

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												One of my favorite games of all-time, and definitely my favorite Double Fine game. Psychonauts is a bundle of joy and love.There is nothing I dislike about this game, at all. I used to play a lot of funny platforming game years and years ago, but don't as much now. I loved playing things like Crash Bandicoot or, going back further generations, to things like Earthworm Jim. When it comes to weird humor though, Psychonauts is probably the top.The story of Psychonauts starts out simple but gets significantly more involved as it goes along, getting decently complex as things actually become a mystery. But the way of solving the puzzles is the best. Delving into the minds of different characters along the way, using their thoughts as levels, is awesome. Each stage in the game is so unique and interesting that I will replay them all forever. All of the characters are so interesting and have their own ticks, and the graphics and sounds (including voice acting) are so well-done. Nothing is wrong at all with the design.Raz, your character, gets interesting power-ups along the way, making exploration fun and opening up random puzzles. Finding the easter eggs in the levels is fun, from the basic collectibles (enabling you to buy upgrades) to especially the memories. The most stand-out ones for me are in Milla's mind, but just about all of them are rewarding in some way.The platforming itself is clean and not too frustrating, though some levels take a bit of adjusting to, such as the angles in the Milkman stage. And exploring outside of the levels is just as fun because Double Fine developed the world with lots of detail. Wandering around and finding some little incidental cutscene is great, especially since nearly everything in the game is really funny and off-the-wall.If you don't find the game's sense of humor enjoyable, then that's a shame. But I have to say that this game is one of the most enjoyable experiences I have ever had. Go play it, now!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												I played "Psychonauts" only now, 10 years after it's been released. And the game holds up very well.This game is a third-person action/platformer with a very strong storyline. You are a boy who wants to become a psychonaut, a secret agent, who has powerfull psychic abilities and can get into the minds of other beings. At the beginning you can't do much, but throughout the game you will become more and more skilled.The graphics is very good and doesn't look old at all. I love the design of levels and characters: very colorful and cartoony.The controls are pretty comfortable. Platformer part of the game is well made. It's satisfying to even just jump around, exploring the world, gathering figments and arrowheads, finding secret bonuses.The game is greatly varied and doesn't let you become bored. All 15 hours that I played, I faced new challenges, interesting plot turns and memorable characters.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												TL;DR: A great story with good gameplay. I recommend you play it, but SPECIFICALLY on Windows, with an Xbox 360 Controller, and with the Psychopad mod.Psychonauts was the first game that I ever bought (with money) on my Steam account. After hearing good reviews (such as the one from Yahtzee on Zero Punctuation), I had decided to pick it up. In the end, I'd consider it one of my favorite games of all time.The core gameplay actually feels a lot like a 3D Mario game. It's a 3rd Person 3D Platformer with some fairly intricate platforming. This difficulty is a little on the tough side, but it never really feels vicious other than the last level of the game. The game gives you a double jump from the beginning of the game, which makes the platforming a bit easier, and about a third of the way through the game, it gives you an ability that allows you to fall slower, which makes some of the later-game platforming more bearable. Your main attack is a punch that has a fairly large range. You also gain abilities as you progress though the game that allow you to attack from more of a distance. For these abilities, the game gives you a lock-on system that is very similar to Zelda's Z-Targeting. This usually works well, but can get frustrating at times when there are a lot of enemies on the screen at once.The level design in this game is excellent. The story behind the levels is that you are entering the minds of different characters, so each level is designed to represent that character's psyche. Because all of the characters you enter the minds of are well characterized, each level is itself a strong representation of the characters. The most interesting levels are correlated to the most interesting characters, with Boyd's level being particularly famous. There are hidden memory vaults, along with scripted events and cutscenes in the levels that help to further characterize the people who's minds you enter, helping to create a better overall connection between the levels you play in and the story that moves the game along.The story in the game is fantastic. You play a psychic boy named Raz who runs away from home (which happens to be a circus), to sneak into a summer camp that trains psychic kids to try to make them "psychic secret agents" called psychonauts. He discovers a conspiracy that threatens the entire camp, and it's up to Raz to save the camp. All the characters that you meet in the game are all well characterized, and makes the story much more interesting. The game has a lot of humor in it, and Double Fine has done a good job of making sure the jokes actually work. Psychonauts is one of the funniest games I've ever played.One aspect of the game that I didn't really like was the leveling system. There are a number of collectables scattered throughout the game (both in the levels and the overworked) that increase your level, and leveling up gives you a few required abilities (for the first few level tiers), then upgrades your existing abilities. Some of these upgrades actually makes the game a LOT easier, meaning that if you don't go out of your way to find these collectables, the game can be much more difficult. However, replaying the game to get 100% of the collectables is a lot of fun. Once you complete the story once, it's a lot of fun to restart the game and aim to get 100% of the collectables and achievements.This game can be downloaded for Windows, Mac OS, and Linux, but the later two ports are actually pretty broken. I played the Mac version first, and I experienced serious performance issues, multiple graphics issues, and crashes. From what I've heard, the linux version doesn't fair much better than the Mac version. While the Windows version isn't perfect, it is certainly better than the other two. You can try to get it to run under Wine, but I can't make any promises about how well that will work.The keyboard+mouse controls for this game really suck. The game was designed around a controller, so you should play it with one. I recommend the 360 controller because the game has controller mapping and vibration support for it. If you have a wireless 360 controller already, just get a cheap Chinese knock-off of the wireless receiver (I can find them for around $10 USD) and force Windows to use the official drivers for it in the Device Manager. The game won't have the button prompts for the controller unless you use the Psychopad mod to add them. Be sure to turn off Steam Cloud Sync before running the patcher though, or the controls may be remapped in such a way to prevent the button prompts from appearing.In the end, I'd recommend this game. I consider this game to be one of my favorite games of all time, and for good reason. It's gameplay is fun, it's story is amazing, and I will always enjoy going back and replaying the game. If you haven't played this game, then you should play it.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Exploring the minds of other campers was so entertaining that I feel it made this game worth it in spite of the near constant crashing issues that seem to plague a segment of the playerbase and the other negatives I'll get to.Pros:-Each level feels distitinct from the others and no one level is "that level" that I hated to play-Story pacing is adequate, I felt introduced to new plot points often enough to remain interested-The characters are fleshed out enough that the player can dig into their pasts and motivations through dialog or power  interactions (claravoiyance lets you see how they view you, for example)-The story was coherent and had a satsifiying conclusion and the main characters exhibited growth as charactersCons:-The player is rewarded with additional powers or upgrades by collecting a large number of collectables but the upgrades feel largely useless and the entire game could be beaten easily while ignoring the collectables-The Confusion grenade power was shoehorned in for one mini-boss and one boss fight in the same level and then has no effect on any enemies following that point.-There is a story-related point where the player recieves the Levitation power but subsequent levels are not designed around its use and it utterly removes all platforming from the game.-Constant crashing. This is only alleviated by the game autosaving at every loading screen so the player loses no progress.-The arrowhead currency is mostly useless except the two times the player is forced to hunt for them to buy an item in order to progress with the game. One of these two items is a dousing rod that only helps find more arrowheads to save up for the more expensive plot-related item.Again, even with the near-useless upgrades and powers, the forced hunting of arrowheads, and constant crashing Psychonauts is worth a play. The characters are interesting, the story is satsifying and not even a slightly lackluster platforming experience can detract from that.

												This game ranks in my top 20 favorite games of all time. While the "graphics" would initially strike most as outdated, what this game lacks in pixels it makes up for 100 fold in brilliant dialoge, character and level design, humor, tight, fun controls and a plot that finally finds a breath of fresh air amongst all the cliches plaguing games right now.The creators of this game - while once well regarded in the videogame community - are now at the butt end of quite a lot of bad press; however this game is the one that I personally believe to be their aboslute treasures. It really takes me back to the days when platforming adventure games like Banjo Kazooie and Super Mario 64 reigned supreme. There are not enough good things I can say about this title. If you've never played it, then you owe it to yourself to pick up a copy asap and let your mind delve into the world of Psychonauts.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												It's a tragedy that there are not more games like this.Psychonauts is a 3rd-person 3D platformer which puts you in the shoes of Raz, a psychic prodigy who ran away from his circus family to join a summer camp for Psychics, in training to become Psychonauts.Psychonauts has you enter the minds of all sorts of different people and experience their inner psyche up close and personal. As you can imagine, this leads to some interesting visual design choices and a lot of laughs to boot.The gameplay is solid, Raz handles pretty well. One downside is that you can only have 3 abilities mapped to buttons at any one time and so you will be switching these constantly depending on the situation. Most of the game has you running around in peoples heads, collecting items and avoiding hazards.The graphics look dated, as they should do. It was an old game and a console port as well. It still holds up well, though, thanks to the great art direction, fluid animations and colorful environments. The audio is also fantastic, it has a great soundtrack and some excellent voice talent.This is a must-have if you're a PC gamer.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Sometimes Double Fine just knocks it out of the park. Psychonauts is an endearing adventure/platforming game that is jam packed with style and charm. You play as Raz a young Psychonaut wannabe who runs away from home to pursue his "dreams" (see what I did there) at Camp Whispering Rock. Raz's ability to penetrate the minds of others creates for a varied and wild experience as each platforming level offers it own unique flavor. My only complaint is that cccassionally the "cute" is broken when Raz gets a bit off-color in his commentary towards the end of the game ... oh, and that they haven't developed a psyquel yet. As fun now as it was when I played it back on the original XBox.  I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2012
												Creative? Original? Funny? Yes, yes, and yes.Psychonauts has joined that list of hipster games. You know the ones: games that everyone missed when they were first released, but we go back to them now because of good word of mouth and constant "top 10" anointment in gaming magazines. Having played Psychonauts apparently makes a person something of a gaming historian. So... I had to try it!While Psychonauts is a true original, it's not without flaws: cut scenes that go on forever; a bizarre lives/hit points system that serves no purpose; a story that wanders about and distracts from the imaginative gameplay; a brutal difficulty curve in the final 3 hours.Still, give it a try. There's nothing else quite like it, and in today's gaming landscape, that alone makes it worth a look.Lastly: Be aware that Double Fine updated this game in 2011 to improve the gameplay on PC, and released a Mac port, too. 5 years after the original release. So classy! Big love for Double Fine!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												This is my backstory to the game, and not a discussion about the actual contents of the game. I wouldn't want to ruin this game for anybody.I was initially introduced to gaming by my father, who played Call of Duty competitively with his clan. He made sure to pick up a copy of the local gaming magazine, which was flourishing at the time, and brought it home. Every copy came with a disk which contained images, music, and game demos. One day, he showed me the demo for a game which very quickly caught my eye. I played this demo over, and over, doing everything possible without cheating to achieve everything one possibly could in the area given to you within this short game demonstration. One day, the game disappeared from my thoughts, and I completely forgot about it, and moved on with my life. Then, one day, I was browsing the Steam Store, and stumbled upon a game by the name of "Psychonauts". The title sounded incredibly familiar, so I went to the Store page of the game, and observed the video. It struck a sense of nostalgia inside of me, and this feeling caused me to buy the game. After waiting for it to install, I started it up. This was it, I realized.The full game of the demo which I had so readily devoured when I was but a wee spawn.This game doesn't reinvent the platforming concept, yet still delivers an experience which feels completely original in every possible sense of the word.Pros: Unique concept, beautifully bizarre art-style, great voice acting, phenomenal use of comedy, original and challenging puzzles.Cons: The game does provide some issues. The puzzles, whilst being original and challenging, can also present a certain sense of frustration at the sometimes sheer amount of abstract thinking one is required to do. If you aren't willing to sit down and invest 2+ hours when you start playing it during the day, afternoon, or evening, you'll miss out on a large part of the experience.Overall, a superb concept, amazingly executed. Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer genre, but makes every aspect of it completely unique to the game.Worth every cent. I eagerly await the sequel.9.3/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Your name is Razputin! But everyone calls you Raz.As your main character, circus-acrobat-turned-psychic-trainee, introduces himself to the others of the Whispering Rock Summer Camp, you begin to know you're in for something special. Welcome to the dark, humorous, and engaging world of Psychonauts.You play as the acrobatic, mentally powerful 10-year-old boy named Razputin, who runs away from his home at the circus to join an elite group of specialized secret agents, the Psychonauts, at their top-secret training facility (which happens to be disguised as a summer camp). There, he more-or-less joins with the other campers to train to one day become a Psychonaut agent. However, when his newfound friends' brains begin to go missing, it's up to Rasputin to locate the mysteriously misplaced cranial matter!The game, for the most part, is a 3D Platformer, but with an interesting take on the genre: You have access to a variety of psychic powers, from clairvoiyance to levitation to telekinesis and everything in between. This allows for a wide variety of challenges within the game, with different approaches to a problem being given (for example, whether to TK a nearby object into an enemy group, or to use Pyrokinesis to set a bombling alight).As the game's levels revolve around entering people's minds to help them solve a problem, the game's several stages are eccentric and often times fantastical, and almost always reflect their person's psychological state of mind; one character with bipolar mood swings has, inside their mind (which is set up like a theater, complete with actors playing the person's memorys), a lamp with a smiling face on one side, and a sorrowful one on the other, and when activated, will distort the memories to reflect the given emoton. One of the levels, Black Velvetopia, holds a special place in this review, for it's excellent backstory, smart level design, beautiful art style, and superb emotional allegory.Even though this may be a game from 2005, the graphic and music still stand out as some of the more strange and original of their kind. The level design is well done, keeping the game familiar yet fresh. The final level seems mostly based around parkour, and grows a tad tedious in the end. Despite this, it is still a great level, and the better parts of the stage outweigh the disappointments. The final boss, however, feels underwhelming, no matter how freaking cool it is.Overall, Psychonauts is a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat, laughing all the way. Easily worth the $10 admission fee. You don't need to be telepathic to know this is a winner.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I've never seen people clamor so hard for a sequel as in the case of Psychonauts. The constant hype and praise heaped onto the game can give people unrealistic expectations and keep them away from it, which is a shame. Before I go into trying to convince you to give it a chance, though, I should point out that it is not a perfect game (while keeping spoilers to a minimum).• As a previous-gen title, the graphics in Psychonauts aren't stellar. They're fine enough to my eyes, but the blurry textures might discourage some.• The PC version is pretty much unplayable without a controller. More on that at the end of this review.• There's a notorious difficulty curve, though less so if you've played other 3D platformers. You'll spend a bit getting used to the controls and game mechanics, sail smooth for the majority of the game (sometimes being thrown a hard puzzle or boss fight), then spend the last level with half your bloodstream composed of adrenaline as you're forced to use everything you've learned under stressful circumstances. The achievement for the last level got its name for a reason.Okay, now I can gush and tell you why you SHOULD play this:• It's funny! I laugh at the same jokes I did when I played it on Xbox years ago, and then some since I'm old enough to understand more of them.• Assuming you're using a controller, the gameplay is flawless. Though you might be tempted to blame the game when you fall or tumble, the acrobatics are of the highest quality, which you would hope for in a platformer.• The story. I won't go into details here, since it's more fun to let you find it all out for yourself. The Steam product description provides a nice teaser, but it's only a small part of the tale.• The characters. Oh boy, this'll be the big bullet point. You wonder why people beg so much for a sequel? This is why. Whispering Rock is a summer camp filled with kids and (technically) employees, with personalities all their own. When I say that the description is only a small part, this is what I'm talking about. Almost all of the characters grow as people through the course of the game's events, and watching them do so is half the fun. Between levels (hell, before you start the first one), you'll want to wander around the campground for a bit and talk to the kids. Pretty much all of them have their own tiny subplots, even if they're just a handful of dialogue spaced out by an hour or two. A band tries to get off the ground, young love is in the air, and boys become men. They're all as compelling. But talking sometimes isn't enough. Some people have their traumatic secrets locked away, and you'll have to seek them out in the darkest corners of their minds.• The levels. This is another area where the game shines. Just like the people and their minds in which you'll find these lands, no two are alike. Again, I'd rather let you find this all out for yourself, but if playing through a Godzilla parody and defeating Napoleon Bonaparte at his own game don't sound appealing, this probably isn't for you.I could probably go on and find more to talk about, but then I'd be contributing to the problem of overhyping the game. It's not for no reason, though. In an industry where the best-selling game are first-person shooters, devoid of atmosphere, denied color, and depicting swaths of people getting killed in massive conflicts, Psychonauts is the antithesis. It's a tribute to childhood adventure presented as a colorful, humorous, varied third-person platformer with no (real) shooting to speak of. When you see 'MODERN BATTLE WAR 2K14: EXTRA GREY EDITION' sell copies by the millions every year, with no sequel in sight for Psychonauts due to underperforming in sales, you might begin to understand why people cling to this game like a liferaft.Is it flawless? No. I spent the entire second paragraph on that.Does it have a deep story making a commentary on the human condition? Probably not, but maybe. Certainly not Raz's; the story of a young boy trying to achieve his childhood dream has been told a thousand times over. But some of Whispering Rock's residents are flawed characters that have suffered genuine tragedy, but who may yet overcome their pasts, if only extended a genuine helping hand (I might be overthinking it, but I just love these characters so much).But the most important thing is that it's fun, which is the basis for a good video game. This is a game full of secrets, collectibles, and challenges. Other games with less have found love, and all the other stuff just made it that much better.This is where the review stops.This is my stop sign.Want to get that awful forced joke? Play the game.-NOTE ON CONTROLLER-Psychonauts' biggest problem is exclusive to the PC version. I HIGHLY recommend using a gamepad. Your best choice is the Xbox 360 Controller, given its high degree of support and close resemblance to the Xbox and PS2 controllers, with which Double Fine designed Psychonauts in mind. However, while you can just plug it in and be ready to go, inexperienced players won't know all of the buttons by heart. Steam user v00d00man has addressed this problem by developing an application called PsychoPad, which will replace the button images with the 360 controller's (or generic gamepad numeric buttons if you opted for something else).http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2151566You might also check out PsychoWide, which crops the cutscenes to your resolution instead of stretching them.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												I quite enjoy this game, as I was not able to play when it came out (just didn't have the money as I was too young to really make any amount of money at the time) but it's nice to have it ported over to Steam. A couple of problems, the mapping for keyboard only is........ Well it leaves something to be desired, it's not game breaking and if you really tried I'm sure it would all make sense, but the worst part of that is if you want to use a controller. Yes yes, I know, no true PC gamer would stray from the mouse and keyboard, but this game was never designed for mouse and keyboard, so I thought obviously using one would be preferred, but it's really not. It auto maps, but some things still require the keyboard and mouse along with it. I found a couple of glitches early on, stuttering frames where some audio cut in and out (nothing terrible, just noticable) and areas where the frames just drop for no apparent reason. But, all in all for a port, this is well worth the money, and coming from someone who can't have his nastalgia goggles on, I'd recommend it for sure.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												If you happen to be a Millennial gamer, Psychonauts needs to be on your gaming short-list.  Equal parts Nintendo platformer, LucasArts adventure, and 1990s era Nickelodeon cartoon, it was tailor-made to put a smile on your face.Whispering Rock Summer Camp is the home of our hero for the duration of the story, and much as Hogwarts instructs young wizards, this retreat is a school for psychics.  Using his mental abilities, Razputin will invade the thoughts of friend and foe alike, and these mindscapes will function as a range of diverse levels.  Ever have somebody tell you that some scary creature was more afraid of you than you were of it?  Raz has one of these moments with a giant mutated lungfish, and upon entering its head, he finds himself filling the role of Godzilla in a city of tiny lungfish.  This type of inventive fun has helped Psychonauts climb onto my own top ten list, and only the most curmudgeonly of cynics would fail to say the same.For a full review, check out:http://amanandhismouse.com/psychonauts.html

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I have to preface this a bit;  I love this game as much as anyone, but it's tedious if you want it to be.  When I first played this, I basically marathoned it over two long sittings.  I did everything I could, completely 100%'d the game.Now, returning to it after having bought it again on sale (Originally played on Xbox), I have to admit the game isn't suited to doing in such a complete fashion again.  Everything holds up, for the most part.  I absolutely adore running around the campgrounds, seeking out various items.  It's pretty basic, but the atmosphere invoked being so similar to that of a Saturday morning cartoon just pulls at my heartstrings something fierce.  When you get into the meat of the game, however, it falls apart a bit.  The platforming is mostly simple, and that's no issue.  It does what it should and it does it well enough.  The game is truly unique in its presentation, that's what makes it worth playing.  The real issue is with the figment collecting.  It's tedious as can be.It's like playing Banjo Kazooie or another collectathon, but everything you want to get, runs away from you.Through walls.It's very frustrating to run through a level more than once to find a chicken that just happens to hide in walls until the very second you turn around.All in all though, wonderful game.  A must play for anyone that loves games in my opinion, just don't get too caught up in seeing every little detail of this game.  The little things just hinder an otherwise amazing game, filled with detail and character not frequently seen.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Inside Someone's MindStory:You take the Role of Raz, who just escaped the life of a circus performer to join a summer camp for children with Psychic abilities, with an unreasonable goal of becoming a Psychonaut in just mere days.Fortunately for Raz or perhaps not. This once peaceful learning camp is now in danger, as kids seem to be turning into TV obsessed Zombies.Its now up to him with the help of his teachers to uncover the culprit.The concept of going inside someone's mind,is what makes this game so appealing to me.You jump between the real world/hub world, a safe and familiar place, to this fantastic sets, showing the mind's representation of each characters fears.Its a great idea, with endless possibilities and Double Fine did good use of it. Every character as their own very distinct personalities and painful memories, each have their own unique mental world.As to what you should expect from the story in this gamePsychonauts started as a turned down idea for Full Throttle, and was the first title for Tim Schafer´s own company, Double Fine.This is what most people used to remember Shafer for, it's a Multi-layered narrative with alot of his own humor and charmGraphics:Psychonauts was never a good looking game, but the strong art style makes up for it in a way.If you ever watched animation around the 90´s, you probably noticed what Psychonauts is going for. All of these characters are human but with desproporcional bodies, sometimes hard to even recognize them as such.That art style extends to the sets themselves and everything fits perfectly togetherGameplay:Not cluttered but a bit all overFrom old school platformers to collectathons, Speed sections on rails and puzzle elements, bosses, fetch-questsyou name it.I will say it, i loved this game, but its hardly a fully fledged platformer, in the later levels it even gets a bit frustrating, calculating and timing your jump, is not always easy, thanks to flawed gameplay mechanicsTLTR?Pros:+Story+art style +Original concept+Variety+Strong characters+Voice acting+Humor+Music (sounds like Danny Elfman)Cons:-Textures-Platforming mechanics -Randomly crashes (not often, +with autosaves it's unlikely to lose progress)Score: 4/5

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Whenever I think about this game I get a tear in my eye because this is one of the most inspired games I've ever seen.. 9.5/10Every level is unique and revolves around a few specific psychic abilities that you're given. What's neat about the abilities is that for most of them, you don't use only one for a level and then stop using it for the rest of the game. Each ability has its place in plenty of areas, from when you get it to the game's end. (The same kind of applies to the items you're given/you buy, many levels have extra goodies for you to go back and obtain with them!)The gameplay is super super fun but the camera can get a bit wonky at times, especially during levels that require elevation(like the area above the theatre level, which made me lose my sh*t :^) )The characters are all excellently characterized and the game does a very good job of thawing out their backstories. Another thing about the characters is they're all incredibly memorable; each and every one of them have fitting (and very talented, may I add) voice actors and unique designs that it's almost hard to forget any of them. (*Note: I am the Milkman.)I remember almost every scene from this game, and I mean maybe that's because it's only been 2-3 months since I've played it buuut I do believe I'll still remember them a year or two from now. Especially Goggalor... GOGGALOR!!!!!To be entirely honest, this is probably one of the best games I have ever played. If I had to give it a personal ranking, it's probably either my second or third favorite video game of all time beside Kingdom Hearts 2.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ guys please, if you're reading this and you're genuinly interested in getting this game, by all means do it. It's definitely worth the price and you will put a good amount of hours into it, especially if you go for a bit of achievement hunting like I did. It'll also make you more excited for the upcoming sequel!!!(which I'm super super hyped for!)

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												First by all, let me say this is not a normal game, this is a masterpiece.As a fan of graphic adventures and of Double Fine i approached to this game with the wrong thinking that it was another adventure with some platform elements, well, i was totally wrong, cause this is a 100% platform with some elements of adventure.This could have been a 100% game but cause of few flaws i can't give to it the top score and i will try to explain why. underlining the negative parts.First thing above all, the camera control is automatic, altough you can manually change it while playing, in the most hot actions you'll not think to change the camera while you're trying to jump and survive, so the result of this is that camera, sometime, suddenly changes making you jump in a wrong direction despite the one you wanted to go, this is a minor problem and happens just in few points but is enough for me to cut some score points.Second thing, i grow up with platforms in a time when graphic adventures (and most of all other kind of games) almost did not exist, so let me say i have quite some experiences in platforms, but this game will, occasionally, challenge your patience, cause some sections of jumps will be extremely annoying.The punching mini game you find in the beginning is one of the most annoying mini games ever i have played in long time, i really think here devs gone a bit too over in demaning things to complete it.Some of the achievements force you to do some of the most annoying grinding gathering you have ever done.The real strength of this game is in the plot and the story, it's very, very nice and will entertain you with a good portion of the best humor you can find inside an insane game (yes because all characters are really insane, literally ^^ )Being a game of 2005, the graphics are amazing, really awesome artworks from great artists.As a my personal opinion and preference i would have preferred that Double Fine had focused more on the adventure portion, adding more puzzles and less platform, but the final result remains outstanding giving to the player an unique gaming experience that will last long thanks to the good longevity of the game.My Final Score is 93 /100

												Originated as a mescaline-induced hallucination of “Full Throttle” playable character Ben, “Psychonauts” deliver truly psychedelic gaming experience, which is augmented by the fact that plot takes place in summer scout camp for psychic kids. And when you get a bit used to all the weirdos there, you start to enter other characters’ minds and delusions — including nut house’s patients, experimented on mutant lake fish, your teachers and yourself. And they differ alot and each delivers its own rules, physics and experience. It easily could have been an inspiration for “Inception” the movie, if it would be weirder.Gameplay is 3D platfomer with slight matroidvania elements.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
												One of the most unique games ever created. In fact, it's more than a game, it's a piece of art. The worlds inside the minds of the characters are mind-blowing, the dialogs are hilarious, the plot is cleverly constructed, and bacon is a beacon. The only thing I didn't like in this game is that most of the characters were designed by 2D artists, and although they look great in the drawings, they look very bad in 3D (see e.g. Crystal and Clem). The last level is not as hard as its reputation suggests, especially since they made it much more forgiving in the Steam version than it is in the GOG version (that one is so old, it still has the Majesco logo).

												Haven't played much of it yet, I'm still at the campsite, but the gameplay is really fun. It's a 3D platformer with fun dialogue and fun combat, it has several collectibles in each level, including 'figments' which are 2D outlines of various things. There are lots of these to collect and it keeps exploration high. You start with pretty basic attacks - a punch combo and a ground pound - but every 10 levels you gain more. If you like 3D platformers, give it a shot. I could compare this to Ty the tasmanian tiger, which had partially similar visuals and controls, they also both had more powers or weapons available as you progressed. If you played and enjoyed Ty, You'll enjoy this.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2011
												Psychonauts is one of the best games I've ever played. It's a third person action/adventure game with a great story about brain theft at a psychic summer camp, and you're thrown into the middle of it as a psychic who ran away from the circus.Being set in a psychic summer camp, you already know you're in for some great special abilities like telekinesis and levitation, but by far the best feature of Psychonauts is that levels are created by entering someone's mind and dealing with all their emotional problems, fighting off the creatures that lurk within, and sorting out their emotional baggage (quite literally). Once you complete a stage, you leave that person in a much better emotional and mental state... well... that's the idea anyway.The musical score, sound effects, and particularly the voice acting is top tier, with the main character, Raz, voiced by Richard Steven Horvitz - who is probably best known as the voice of Invader Zim or maybe as Daggett from Angry Beavers.As good as Psychonauts is, it does have a few issues. The camera angle can be a bit annoying at times, but it's mostly alright. Also, I found myself unable to beat the game using a keyboard and mouse setup - one of the later levels has some platforming that felt impossible, but after I got myself an Xbox 360 controller I was able to get past that tricky section, so I'd say a decent controller is an absolute must.10 out of 10 I don't care if it had a few minor issues, the rest was so good I couldn't possibly give it a lower score.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Originated as a mescaline-induced hallucination of “Full Throttle” playable character Ben, “Psychonauts” deliver truly psychedelic gaming experience, which is augmented by the fact that plot takes place in summer scout camp for psychic kids. And when you get a bit used to all the weirdos there, you start to enter other characters’ minds and delusions — including nut house’s patients, experimented on mutant lake fish, your teachers and yourself. And they differ alot and each delivers its own rules, physics and experience. It easily could have been an inspiration for “Inception” the movie, if it would be weirder.Gameplay is 3D platfomer with slight matroidvania elements.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												It took me a while to find this game, and when I did find it, I wasn't in a rush to buy it, as the screenshots on the store page didn't appeal to me that much. I ended up buying it with a few other games, not in a bundle, just together. I left it in my library for a few months, and I got bored and played it.... And I didn't stop until I finished it.You will regret your purchase of this game, but the part you will regret is not the money, but the time in which you waited until you played it. I know I regret it, I regret that I didn't find this game earlier, that I didn't play it WHEN it came out. But it's not too late to play, and the game has aged quite well (not that it was that old anyway). What makes this game so good that I am building it up so much? Everything about it is good.The whole theme of this game is insanity and telepathy. These themes are darkly and nicely woven into the levels and into the game. Going into other people's minds and seeing dark recesses of insane asyulms. Characters who are strange and twisted, phycopaths, Narcissists, multiple personalities, suicidal children, etc. The characters in this game will not disapoint, especially not Mr. Pokeylope. ;)The graphics stlyes are different depending on environment, which gives a very nice feeling to the game. It can be very dark and colourful, and go to being very bright and cheery. Which makes it practically impossibe to completely hate the stlye of the game, if you don't like the dark levels, you'll like the bright levels, but sometimes, you like all the levels.There is very little wrong with this game, some achievements are hard to get (but that's a plus), but other than that, you have little reason to not buy this game and play it. It is sitting up as one of my favourite (if not favourite) game. It was just such an enjoyable experience to play, and it's one that doesn't seem to be played by as many as it should be.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I've never seen people clamor so hard for a sequel as in the case of Psychonauts. The constant hype and praise heaped onto the game can give people unrealistic expectations and keep them away from it, which is a shame. Before I go into trying to convince you to give it a chance, though, I should point out that it is not a perfect game (while keeping spoilers to a minimum).• As a previous-gen title, the graphics in Psychonauts aren't stellar. They're fine enough to my eyes, but the blurry textures might discourage some.• The PC version is pretty much unplayable without a controller. More on that at the end of this review.• There's a notorious difficulty curve, though less so if you've played other 3D platformers. You'll spend a bit getting used to the controls and game mechanics, sail smooth for the majority of the game (sometimes being thrown a hard puzzle or boss fight), then spend the last level with half your bloodstream composed of adrenaline as you're forced to use everything you've learned under stressful circumstances. The achievement for the last level got its name for a reason.Okay, now I can gush and tell you why you SHOULD play this:• It's funny! I laugh at the same jokes I did when I played it on Xbox years ago, and then some since I'm old enough to understand more of them.• Assuming you're using a controller, the gameplay is flawless. Though you might be tempted to blame the game when you fall or tumble, the acrobatics are of the highest quality, which you would hope for in a platformer.• The story. I won't go into details here, since it's more fun to let you find it all out for yourself. The Steam product description provides a nice teaser, but it's only a small part of the tale.• The characters. Oh boy, this'll be the big bullet point. You wonder why people beg so much for a sequel? This is why. Whispering Rock is a summer camp filled with kids and (technically) employees, with personalities all their own. When I say that the description is only a small part, this is what I'm talking about. Almost all of the characters grow as people through the course of the game's events, and watching them do so is half the fun. Between levels (hell, before you start the first one), you'll want to wander around the campground for a bit and talk to the kids. Pretty much all of them have their own tiny subplots, even if they're just a handful of dialogue spaced out by an hour or two. A band tries to get off the ground, young love is in the air, and boys become men. They're all as compelling. But talking sometimes isn't enough. Some people have their traumatic secrets locked away, and you'll have to seek them out in the darkest corners of their minds.• The levels. This is another area where the game shines. Just like the people and their minds in which you'll find these lands, no two are alike. Again, I'd rather let you find this all out for yourself, but if playing through a Godzilla parody and defeating Napoleon Bonaparte at his own game don't sound appealing, this probably isn't for you.I could probably go on and find more to talk about, but then I'd be contributing to the problem of overhyping the game. It's not for no reason, though. In an industry where the best-selling game are first-person shooters, devoid of atmosphere, denied color, and depicting swaths of people getting killed in massive conflicts, Psychonauts is the antithesis. It's a tribute to childhood adventure presented as a colorful, humorous, varied third-person platformer with no (real) shooting to speak of. When you see 'MODERN BATTLE WAR 2K14: EXTRA GREY EDITION' sell copies by the millions every year, with no sequel in sight for Psychonauts due to underperforming in sales, you might begin to understand why people cling to this game like a liferaft.Is it flawless? No. I spent the entire second paragraph on that.Does it have a deep story making a commentary on the human condition? Probably not, but maybe. Certainly not Raz's; the story of a young boy trying to achieve his childhood dream has been told a thousand times over. But some of Whispering Rock's residents are flawed characters that have suffered genuine tragedy, but who may yet overcome their pasts, if only extended a genuine helping hand (I might be overthinking it, but I just love these characters so much).But the most important thing is that it's fun, which is the basis for a good video game. This is a game full of secrets, collectibles, and challenges. Other games with less have found love, and all the other stuff just made it that much better.This is where the review stops.This is my stop sign.Want to get that awful forced joke? Play the game.-NOTE ON CONTROLLER-Psychonauts' biggest problem is exclusive to the PC version. I HIGHLY recommend using a gamepad. Your best choice is the Xbox 360 Controller, given its high degree of support and close resemblance to the Xbox and PS2 controllers, with which Double Fine designed Psychonauts in mind. However, while you can just plug it in and be ready to go, inexperienced players won't know all of the buttons by heart. Steam user v00d00man has addressed this problem by developing an application called PsychoPad, which will replace the button images with the 360 controller's (or generic gamepad numeric buttons if you opted for something else).http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2151566You might also check out PsychoWide, which crops the cutscenes to your resolution instead of stretching them.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												First by all, let me say this is not a normal game, this is a masterpiece.As a fan of graphic adventures and of Double Fine i approached to this game with the wrong thinking that it was another adventure with some platform elements, well, i was totally wrong, cause this is a 100% platform with some elements of adventure.This could have been a 100% game but cause of few flaws i can't give to it the top score and i will try to explain why. underlining the negative parts.First thing above all, the camera control is automatic, altough you can manually change it while playing, in the most hot actions you'll not think to change the camera while you're trying to jump and survive, so the result of this is that camera, sometime, suddenly changes making you jump in a wrong direction despite the one you wanted to go, this is a minor problem and happens just in few points but is enough for me to cut some score points.Second thing, i grow up with platforms in a time when graphic adventures (and most of all other kind of games) almost did not exist, so let me say i have quite some experiences in platforms, but this game will, occasionally, challenge your patience, cause some sections of jumps will be extremely annoying.The punching mini game you find in the beginning is one of the most annoying mini games ever i have played in long time, i really think here devs gone a bit too over in demaning things to complete it.Some of the achievements force you to do some of the most annoying grinding gathering you have ever done.The real strength of this game is in the plot and the story, it's very, very nice and will entertain you with a good portion of the best humor you can find inside an insane game (yes because all characters are really insane, literally ^^ )Being a game of 2005, the graphics are amazing, really awesome artworks from great artists.As a my personal opinion and preference i would have preferred that Double Fine had focused more on the adventure portion, adding more puzzles and less platform, but the final result remains outstanding giving to the player an unique gaming experience that will last long thanks to the good longevity of the game.My Final Score is 93 /100

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Haven't played much of it yet, I'm still at the campsite, but the gameplay is really fun. It's a 3D platformer with fun dialogue and fun combat, it has several collectibles in each level, including 'figments' which are 2D outlines of various things. There are lots of these to collect and it keeps exploration high. You start with pretty basic attacks - a punch combo and a ground pound - but every 10 levels you gain more. If you like 3D platformers, give it a shot. I could compare this to Ty the tasmanian tiger, which had partially similar visuals and controls, they also both had more powers or weapons available as you progressed. If you played and enjoyed Ty, You'll enjoy this.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												I quite enjoy this game, as I was not able to play when it came out (just didn't have the money as I was too young to really make any amount of money at the time) but it's nice to have it ported over to Steam. A couple of problems, the mapping for keyboard only is........ Well it leaves something to be desired, it's not game breaking and if you really tried I'm sure it would all make sense, but the worst part of that is if you want to use a controller. Yes yes, I know, no true PC gamer would stray from the mouse and keyboard, but this game was never designed for mouse and keyboard, so I thought obviously using one would be preferred, but it's really not. It auto maps, but some things still require the keyboard and mouse along with it. I found a couple of glitches early on, stuttering frames where some audio cut in and out (nothing terrible, just noticable) and areas where the frames just drop for no apparent reason. But, all in all for a port, this is well worth the money, and coming from someone who can't have his nastalgia goggles on, I'd recommend it for sure.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Inside Someone's MindStory:You take the Role of Raz, who just escaped the life of a circus performer to join a summer camp for children with Psychic abilities, with an unreasonable goal of becoming a Psychonaut in just mere days.Fortunately for Raz or perhaps not. This once peaceful learning camp is now in danger, as kids seem to be turning into TV obsessed Zombies.Its now up to him with the help of his teachers to uncover the culprit.The concept of going inside someone's mind,is what makes this game so appealing to me.You jump between the real world/hub world, a safe and familiar place, to this fantastic sets, showing the mind's representation of each characters fears.Its a great idea, with endless possibilities and Double Fine did good use of it. Every character as their own very distinct personalities and painful memories, each have their own unique mental world.As to what you should expect from the story in this gamePsychonauts started as a turned down idea for Full Throttle, and was the first title for Tim Schafer´s own company, Double Fine.This is what most people used to remember Shafer for, it's a Multi-layered narrative with alot of his own humor and charmGraphics:Psychonauts was never a good looking game, but the strong art style makes up for it in a way.If you ever watched animation around the 90´s, you probably noticed what Psychonauts is going for. All of these characters are human but with desproporcional bodies, sometimes hard to even recognize them as such.That art style extends to the sets themselves and everything fits perfectly togetherGameplay:Not cluttered but a bit all overFrom old school platformers to collectathons, Speed sections on rails and puzzle elements, bosses, fetch-questsyou name it.I will say it, i loved this game, but its hardly a fully fledged platformer, in the later levels it even gets a bit frustrating, calculating and timing your jump, is not always easy, thanks to flawed gameplay mechanicsTLTR?Pros:+Story+art style +Original concept+Variety+Strong characters+Voice acting+Humor+Music (sounds like Danny Elfman)Cons:-Textures-Platforming mechanics -Randomly crashes (not often, +with autosaves it's unlikely to lose progress)Score: 4/5

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Whenever I think about this game I get a tear in my eye because this is one of the most inspired games I've ever seen.. 9.5/10Every level is unique and revolves around a few specific psychic abilities that you're given. What's neat about the abilities is that for most of them, you don't use only one for a level and then stop using it for the rest of the game. Each ability has its place in plenty of areas, from when you get it to the game's end. (The same kind of applies to the items you're given/you buy, many levels have extra goodies for you to go back and obtain with them!)The gameplay is super super fun but the camera can get a bit wonky at times, especially during levels that require elevation(like the area above the theatre level, which made me lose my sh*t :^) )The characters are all excellently characterized and the game does a very good job of thawing out their backstories. Another thing about the characters is they're all incredibly memorable; each and every one of them have fitting (and very talented, may I add) voice actors and unique designs that it's almost hard to forget any of them. (*Note: I am the Milkman.)I remember almost every scene from this game, and I mean maybe that's because it's only been 2-3 months since I've played it buuut I do believe I'll still remember them a year or two from now. Especially Goggalor... GOGGALOR!!!!!To be entirely honest, this is probably one of the best games I have ever played. If I had to give it a personal ranking, it's probably either my second or third favorite video game of all time beside Kingdom Hearts 2.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ guys please, if you're reading this and you're genuinly interested in getting this game, by all means do it. It's definitely worth the price and you will put a good amount of hours into it, especially if you go for a bit of achievement hunting like I did. It'll also make you more excited for the upcoming sequel!!!(which I'm super super hyped for!)

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I have to preface this a bit;  I love this game as much as anyone, but it's tedious if you want it to be.  When I first played this, I basically marathoned it over two long sittings.  I did everything I could, completely 100%'d the game.Now, returning to it after having bought it again on sale (Originally played on Xbox), I have to admit the game isn't suited to doing in such a complete fashion again.  Everything holds up, for the most part.  I absolutely adore running around the campgrounds, seeking out various items.  It's pretty basic, but the atmosphere invoked being so similar to that of a Saturday morning cartoon just pulls at my heartstrings something fierce.  When you get into the meat of the game, however, it falls apart a bit.  The platforming is mostly simple, and that's no issue.  It does what it should and it does it well enough.  The game is truly unique in its presentation, that's what makes it worth playing.  The real issue is with the figment collecting.  It's tedious as can be.It's like playing Banjo Kazooie or another collectathon, but everything you want to get, runs away from you.Through walls.It's very frustrating to run through a level more than once to find a chicken that just happens to hide in walls until the very second you turn around.All in all though, wonderful game.  A must play for anyone that loves games in my opinion, just don't get too caught up in seeing every little detail of this game.  The little things just hinder an otherwise amazing game, filled with detail and character not frequently seen.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												If you happen to be a Millennial gamer, Psychonauts needs to be on your gaming short-list.  Equal parts Nintendo platformer, LucasArts adventure, and 1990s era Nickelodeon cartoon, it was tailor-made to put a smile on your face.Whispering Rock Summer Camp is the home of our hero for the duration of the story, and much as Hogwarts instructs young wizards, this retreat is a school for psychics.  Using his mental abilities, Razputin will invade the thoughts of friend and foe alike, and these mindscapes will function as a range of diverse levels.  Ever have somebody tell you that some scary creature was more afraid of you than you were of it?  Raz has one of these moments with a giant mutated lungfish, and upon entering its head, he finds himself filling the role of Godzilla in a city of tiny lungfish.  This type of inventive fun has helped Psychonauts climb onto my own top ten list, and only the most curmudgeonly of cynics would fail to say the same.For a full review, check out:http://amanandhismouse.com/psychonauts.html
